Isaac Ducoign Aug 5 1854
Dunbarton Aug 15 1854
$20.00 encl
lLL. Central Freight House Office
Ducoign Station, Perry Co. Illinois
8 oclock. Saturday Evening Aug. 5 1854
My Dearest Wife
Well! The labors of another week are over. I have just filed away the papers--you know what a mass of them are found on my desk on working days--put away the plans & note books & time files &c.; locked up the safe; and sat myself comfortable down thinking of my Ettie & my Baby; and rejoicing to have an Ettie and a Baby Mayo to remember & think of. Can you imagine me here? Do not think of the Old dark, low ceiled, & dirty Old DuQuoin Office. This you know is a very different place. You remember the large Frame Charles was just putting up when you left here. --On the west side of R.R. Track--(4 or 5 feet up from the ground, and no platform or steps yet built) In the S.E. Corner (next the Tap. House) a room finished off only 12 X 14 (but 12 feet high, plastered bright & white; on the East one great window 9 ft.  high x 5 ft. wide, On the Northside stands the big Office Table, N.W. a door into the main building. South the large outside door. S.W. a big Bookcase, made on purpose, and under it the Safe. S.E. Corner (between door & window), my same old Desk A great house linen curtains to the window. I sit of course at the desk, with my face partly toward the window--not in Ettie's Chair, for that is in the sleeping apartment, that is, part of a floor laid overheard, in the big open building. I guess you can form a tolerable idea of it. Another thing; the good pine floor has a bushel or two of wastepapers on it.

Last week Saturday I did not get any letter from you; but on Tuesday Aug. 1st before I went North I did, your good letter of July 19th or 20th, written soon after you reached Dunbarton, and which I was anxious to get to learn of your prosperous journey & safe arrival at Dunbarton. I had before got a letter from Eliab mentioning that you had left Bangor. By Tuesday mail also I got a nice letter from Lucy with a little one from Maria also. I had slight hopes to get another from you today; but got no letter at all: though a fine lot of Newspapers including the Independent & a Congregational Herald.
By the way does Putnam's Monthly come to Dunbarton regularly? It should. I am much obliged to you for your account of all your journey etc I can realize all about you much better for your writing the particulars. Keep doing so. I am glad you went to Old Town Sc. I am glad you got Mayo vaccinated--hope it took well, and was good. I am anxious to hear from it again. 
I expect you are likely to be disappointed of your visit at Dunbarton from the DeWitts. Lucy & Maria wrote that they had reckoned up their spendings, & found them $500.00; and as they had had part of a chance to visit you at Bangor &c. they were about regretfully concluding to hasten home without going to Dunbarton at all. 
Ettie--dearest Ettie--I would not keep Sabra at any rate if she does not suit you. I did not think so much of it before. But from what Mother & Lucy & Maria all write--you have not written me enough about her it is plain that she is a trouble to you. I judge she is not pleasant even, or really good to Mayo. I expect

she is a sort of uneasy discontented gloomy person decidedly unpleasant to you. I fear she has troubled you a good deal. If you can make her do the housework, washing etc & all cooking, relieving Mother entirely of all care of those things; have her do so, and keep her by all means, but keep yourself and Mayo away from her as much as you can. If necessary keep Jenny out of school; teach her yourself, if you like, more & better things than she could learn in School, or give her my word for for it that she shall have better chances to go to School sometime. Perhaps you can get some other girl to suit you, and both dispense entirely with Sabra, and send Jenny to School. At any rate-suit yourself perfectly & fully in some way--acting "as one having authority"--one that must necessarily be fully suited in some way--Will you not? Ettie!
Lucy worries for fear you did not enjoy your visit there among so much confusing & changing help etc. She says it was the worst time in that respect that she ever had -- but promises better times when you come back in the Fall! Percie's vaccination did not take. I want to hear about Mayo's. They have got a Daguerrotype of Percie. Maria writes about your being very good there in some respects; but that you were naughty in one very bad particular. You would "Sew. Sew."!!! Now Ettie-don't do so any more - dont dont. Why I had rather hear that you were doing housework, or taking care of the Baby, or washing, or cooking or any thing almost. In any such thing you would have a sense of fatigue as a better defined limit to tell you when to stop. But in so sewing you might keep on so sewing till you killed yourself almost. I know it cannot be good for you to do so.

Oh Ettie -- if you do not, as I am somewhat inclined to believe, care any thing at all for yourself, do Ettie, on my account, and on Little May's account, do take care of your health, do. The sewing so much must certainly be injurious to you--the worst thing you could do. I do believe you would have now been fatter & stronger & in better health every way, if you had not sewed so much at Bangor. Just think of it now, and realize that your duty to your dear little Boy will not allow of it. I want to hear of your riding and running, and walking about - all round the Town, in wood or pastures after flowers or berries or mosses, or gossiping with the neighbors, or any where except sitting & sewing sewing. I would give a hundred dollars to know you did not touch a needle for three months--I am sure you could find enough else to do. Writing letters & reading what you would want to would surely be sedentary employment enough for you. Now of course you will think I am unreasonable. (I know I am-but then--) and would talk about the "necessity" of sewing--but then I do not believe in such necessity--As long as Shops contain all descriptions of every thing ready made--and you have money to pay for them, or for hiring work done to suit you--There Ettie! if you will forgive all this I will try not to do so again--Did I tell you what I have done the past week--(I always write you my record I believe) - Well not much I guess. Monday I went down to Big Muddy on Hand Car. to attend to very many things there & at DeSoto, and to see to Time of work of men along the track for July. Mitchell's sickness (He is not out yet, though better) makes me additional work. Came up on Express Train Tuesday (Aug 1st) in office till 3 P.M. Then with Thermometer at 101 F. in coolest of positions in shade started north. Little Muddy at Night. Wednesday to Richmond & Centralia. Thursday back again to Little Muddy. Then a fine little shower at Night, cooling the air which had been over 100 F. for many days. Friday Home & down to Old Town to see Mitchell. Saturday here in office all day. Most Affectionately, I.S.

Isaac Aug 27 - 1854 - Ducoign Ills.
Dunbarton Sept. 5 1854
Ducoign Perry Co. Illinois, Aug 27 '54
Dearest E.
Here I am again at Ducoign; seated at the same old Desk and writing again to my dear wife. I wrote to you - or pretended to - in much haste--a bit of a letter while at St Louis the other day. That letter you will doubtless get long before this--Perhaps even before the one mailed here some days before. I got back here from St Louis last night 9 P.M. Left St Louis on Friday morning by rail to Carlyle, stayed there three or four hours & then out to Centralia with my horses which I had left there as I went in. Saturday in forenoon came down to Little Muddy, and at night down here. It was really uncomfortable in St Louis. A City is always uncomfortable in hot weather, and St Louis seems unusually so. There is no benefit of the breeze in the city--and that you know is the principal thing we live upon in the Prairie. The nights too seem still hotter than the days. Why I could hardly sleep at all the two nights I was in St Louis. And then the Misquitoes, are certainly worse there in the city of St Louis than I have seen them any where else at the west. No one can sleep without Mosquito Bars -- and those you know I dislike  At Carlyle, stopping there to look after Lumber, Casting and other freight coming in for the R.R. I was much exposed to the extremely hot sun, and got heated so I did not feel quite so well that night.

that night at Centralia, or all the next day; But for? today am well as ever again. I will be careful the next time about exposing myself too much to the SunShine. 
Your last letter of Aug. 10th I got at the Mt Hawking P.O. after I left here last Monday night; and it made me glad all the way all the week. It is too bad be be kept so far away, and makes me not a little sad and grieved sometimes--but then, as Charles says, it is a good thing to have a wife, even if one cannot be with here--Yes especially if one has as good a wife as my Ettie! 
It is so sickly there in New Hampshire, and everywhere there among the hills, that I am really afraid to have my family remain there! If I could only have them out here on these healthy prairies! Really it does seem that it must be very sickly there, and it is certainly very healthy here about Ducoign so far this Season--though throughout the country it is called a very sickly season. It has been really sickly in some places. 
Oh I do so want to see Mayo! His Daguerrotype is a great comfort to me. I am so much obliged to you for it. Is Mayo really afraid of grown persons?--you say he is pleased with children but will not speak to grown persons. Does he cry when they speak to him? How much does he weigh? So I supposed that Father & Mother have not yet got home if they were to be gone three weeks. Or were they to get home yesterday. I hope you did not get lonesome & homesick. But you will write to me all about it. I hope they have a very pleasant visit--and it does them much good. Is it curious--I have here I went out to water my horses, and coming back couldn't imagine what was curious. Finally by tracing over the whole long train of thought I find it was that I have

never seen any of your relatives.--that is except our own folks. Some time we may have more leisure. You write that Mayo is out every day. Is Ettie out with him? You say she tries to be well & fat & strong. How? By sitting still and so sowing so ing all the time in the house? or how
Do you be out of doors at least seven hours every day? That is when it does not rain, and then out in the shed or running about in the house with doors open. Oh Ettie, My Ettie, My Dear Ettie, do take care of your health and strength. Of what consequence is a little miserable paltry sewing compared with your health and strength to Isaac & Mayo.
The Track Laying has at last commenced again here--though it will probably advance rather slowly for a week or two--till we can get the Big Muddy Bridge up--Then we intend to crowd it as rapidly as possible. Mr Wm Crosby is not very well just now; attacked yesterday with symptoms of ague or rather perhaps Billious or Remittent Fever: But I hope he will soon get over it. Mr Mitchell is getting quite Smart again--says he walked nearly ten miles yesterday. Mr Rowley & the rest are quite well. Mr Rowley I think I mentioned went in to St Louis with me. Rowley Smith & Co expect to get through here in about a month longer. Mr Smith has not yet got back is expected soon now. I have not been to Meeting today. I got home considerably tired last night, and sleepy. Had hardly had a real good night's rest for the whole week. So I got up to Breakfast decidedly late, and

and after Breakfast retired again to my little cot and spend most of the remaining forenoon in reading the Independent.
I got several Books at St Louis "Sunlight through the Mist" I have to M.E. Roots as I came back after reading it in the way. An evangelical Episcopal Book for Children. Mrs Beecher Stowe's "Sunny Memories"--I don't know as I shall have time to read it--Have you not ere this got it & read it--Write to me about it. --"My Schools & Schoolmasters" Hugh Miller's Autobiography I talk of giving to Mitchell if he will read it--or perhaps I shall too--Dickens "Hard Times"--Ruskin's "Lectures on Art Nature & Painting"--author you remember of Books Anne was praising so much at Elyria "Stones of Venice" "Seven Lamps of Architecture" I do mean to find some time to read--have not however so far this summer. My leisure from business has been only to read the Newspapers & to write to Ettie--By the way, you have plenty of time to read this summer & I hasn't. Why do you not read some books which JJ have read, & you have not, and write to me about them? Would it not be a good plan for both of us?
Oh My Dearest Wife Ettie, who will you not send me a really good Daguerrotype picture of your own nice little Self--about a V worth at least--perhaps a full length--in a light frame or case to send by mail. Do Ettie--Come, I would give more than that to please my Ettie--and you need not grudge just a V or X worth to send to me.
Charles has hardly decided yet when to return East. Colling Dunham has left the Road & gone home East. Oh Ettie! How like a heathen I do live here--only to think of it here ever since the 2d week in June most three months--I believe I have heard but one single sermon preached--That is all the has been preached at DuQuoin except by Methodists. To be sure I have been obliged to read some sermons myself Now - think of it--how I do need an Ettie to take care of me I am getting still more careless about going to Meeting keep me good--I do not know but I ought to have gone down to Meeting today.--but then I was tired & sleepy and did not feel a bit like Reading a long hard sermon to em. Good Bye, Isaac

Isaac - Centralia Sept 3, 1854
Dunbarton Sept. 9 - 1854 -
Centralia, Sabbath, Sept. 3d 1854
My Dearest Wife
Here I am away from Home over Sunday. It is the first time this Summer. I cam rather unexpectedly  Mr Mason & Mr Burrall came up from the First Division on Friday Night, stopped with me at Ducoign over night , and then came up with me here on yesterday; leaving me here over Sunday. It is not much of a Sunday place--there are no Meeting--only a great lot of men mechanics &c. loafing about, sleeping & writing letters, &c. I hear however that there is a Camp Meeting two or three miles off, & perhaps I may go over there this afternoon. Your last letter I received joyfully last Tuesday on my way up here. I wish I had it here today to read over again. I staid at Ducoign last Monday. Tuesday came up to Little Muddy, remaining there most of the day; up to Centralia in the night, the weather being very hot. Staid here all day Wednesday - Wednesday night rode to Little Muddy Thursday morning to Ducoign. Friday down to Elk Prairie and Big Muddy. And Saturday up here again. So I made out quite a week: traveling about. Very hot weather all the time too. Mr Mason & Mr Burrall (who you know is President I.C.R.R.) seemed in very good spirits. We had got along better here than they expected; and they seemed very well pleased with the Contractors and Engineers

By the way let me tell you now. You may have read in the Newspapers about the celebrated "Minesota Land Fill" This last Congress you know passed a Bill giving a large grant of land to Minesota for a Great Rail Road Line. There was to have been a great R.R. Co. to build the road 400 miles long. R.B. Mason was to have been Chief Engineer. I.S. Metcalf of 2 Div. was to have had a good place on it--to have gone on this Fall & Winter to making the first Surveys as soon as he could get away from this. Well the Bill as passed by Congress confirmed the whole project, and established it as, in the present expressed state of R.R. Affairs, about the only large project to go vigorously forward this Winter. But--there was some roguery about transcribing the Bill--after it was passed It was altered in some particulars--which made a good deal of noise about it--and Congress finally repealed the Bill altogether. their stopping the Whole project for the present. Mr. Mason says however it will doubtless pass again the next session, & the the Road go on: and the said I.S. Metcalf shall have a place on it. But it is to be expected that the said Metcalf will have a Vacation between now & then. The Pressure in the Money Market you know is very severe now. The funds of their Co. you know are abundant, but then when money is worth 11 to 24 per cent in New York, monied men do not like to use money even in the best R.R. Investments. So Our folks wish to entrench here as much as convenient--put off till next year whatever they can conveniently. So that I shall put up here only what we want most, and probably get through by the

by the first of January next. So what do you say to coming out here as soon as it becomes cool & healthy? Do you want to? I do want to see my Ettie--and my Mayo. It will be rather a short time to come out so far for--but then we could take our time, and go back at our leisure. Now think of it, and decide what you will do. Consider the matter and write all you think about it. One thing has done me considerable good, really gone some ways towards restoring my good confidence in human nature, or in Mankind. You know it was supposed that R.B. Mason had lost very heavily by the failure & deflection of Robert Schuyler. He supposed so himself--until he went east this Summer; When he found in Robert Schuyler's Safe a package marked "Private Papers of R.B. Mason"--sealed up which was found to contain fifty or sixty thousand dollars in R.R. Stocks & Bonds (Mr. Mason's property deposited with or loaned to Schuyler and which he supposed gone) and a note to Mr Mason saying that whatever he had been guilty of towards others, he would try to be just to Mr Mason. Now isn't that worth while? It really did me good. Just think how hard it would have been, if he had been as expected ruined by his best friend, his whole property lost, and at his age to begin the work as it were anew--with his large family--a very expensive family, and with their habits of expense formed--that is a great thing. For you & I now the loss or gain of property is a slight affair. We can do without it and not hurt us--But say 20 years hence if we should live with a family around us, living in luxury, and habits all formed and fixed--the loss of property then is a dreadful thing. Mr J.C. Smith has got back--will probably be at Big Muddy

Big Muddy this winter Rowley Smith & Co. will get through with their business, as a firm, and get away from the 2nd Div. probably this month or by first of next. 
Noel will go to his farm. Post to Cairo probably Smith to Big Muddy and Rowley I know not where. Write to me all about what you think of coming back here this fall. And how you would like to live a few years in Minnesota. Oh Ettie I haven't any French Testament here to read over our Two Chapters in. What shall I do -- I have not failed of it before. Perhaps though I can find One, Aspem the German foreman is here, and he a French scholar--perhaps he has one. I guess though I shall go to the Camp Meeting this afternoon. I will write again when I get time. I fear this isn't a very good Sunday letter. Much love to Father & Mother, who I suppose have now returned and all. Write to me all about everything--Most truly
Isaac S.M.

{Isaac, Ducoign Sept;7.1854
Dunbarton Sept. 16, 1854}
Ducoign Perry Co. Ill. Sept. 7. 1854
My Dearest Ettie,
I have before me two of your last letter really unanswered. One of them however I received before I wrote to you last but did not have it with me when I wrote I went to Centralia on Saturday last with Col. Mason and Presdt Burrall, and remaining there over Sunday wrote a lot of letters to you, & sent to St Louis Monday Morning. Sunday, after visiting that Cellar I went off to a Camp Meeting. Meth. Epis. on Fulton Creek, 3 or 4 miles from Centralia. It did not amount to much--had comparatively few present on account of the Drouth, etc etc. (They were hauling water to drink about two miles) No feed etc. I heard an ignorant fellow (old Sub Contractor on R.R. "preach a funeral" for a child which died last spring". Very worthless afterwards some remarks by the Elder, which were better. Then the Communion--but somehow the receiving the sacrament kneeling, as the Methodists do. (East that is not essential, but here it is the rule) does not suit me. It has a savor of priesthood about it. I should think the officiating officer Bishop rather than Elder. The Camp Meeting--was a bit of pulpit of rough sticks boards under a tree with flatted logs ranged around and all about the Tent--some of the Big Wagons of the country with their cloth covers--Morey's? wagons some wooden camps like those you saw at Peter Hagler's meeting house--some tents made of Bed blankets, or only cotton cloth & sheets &c.&tc.

I staid at the Camp Meeting till about sunset (It was to be kept up that evening and two days longer) Then rode on to Little Muddy 25 or 30 miles. Oh! You can imagine nothing in a New England Climate at all equal to the nights here nowadays. A moonlight that puts one in mind of the Italian's claim that "The Moon of Naples was better than the English Sun" An atmosphere--I will give it up--there is nothing I can compare it to. For Mildness & dryness possibly one might mention the atmosphere of a room heated by an airtight stove in the most favorable circumstances. It seems so dry, so pure, so clear--that a particle of moisture--In fact we have almost forgot there is such a thing. Just imagine nights so warm that you are perfectly comfortable with the least or thinnest possible clothing, or none at all--and yet after you are used to it--not at all too warm--and at the same time so pure & dry--as that there has not been a particle of dew for months. 
Monday, at Little Muddy, Track till P.M. then down here. Tuesday A.M. here, P.M. to DeSoto. Wednesday Big Muddy.--Here at night. Thursday Here, up the Track, trying to settle for fat oxen the Train killed yesterday &c. &c.  fuller of business all the time I am, than any bag in this country is of potatoes this year I know--for there isn't any. In fact, with excess of head work--my head fairly aches now--and I will stop & go to Bed

Yesterday I got a letter from Mother of Aug. 27th announcing a little neice at Bangor: and the good projects of Mother & Child. Very good news. You probably heard it though before I did. I received a letter this week, three days since from Eliab & Maria of 18th Aug. I am somewhat afraid for the business of Eliab & Samuel nowadays. There is an extreme pressure in the money market at present. Mr Burrall said as bad as he ever knew; the very best paper 1 1/2 per cent per month etc. If it is as bad in Bangor, I am afraid they may not be able to weather it. They have not a great deal of Capital you know. And Samuel's logs have not come down, so that they have not seen what they expected. Their Backers I suppose are wealthy--but then in such monetary crises, the men of large invested capital may be no better off if their funds are not at call. 
Well it is rather busy times just now, and I have plenty else to write & do--and so I will stop writing to my dear wife for this time. Probably write again on Sunday.
Sincerely
Isaac S.

{Isaac September 10. 1854
Ducoigne
Dunbarton " 19. 1854
Sabbath Morning, September 10th 1854
It is a morning of most brilliant & unclouded beauty. The sun rises up into the sky blazing in Majesty, and the broad prairie is resplendent in its glare. Far on the western horizon are various bits of straggling irregular clouds, like the scattered squadrons of a vanquished army, and, even while watched, fast disappearing in their eager flight. The sun does certainly look like a mighty conqueror. (Maybe partly on account of our personal experience of his prowess) But this morning his rays are simply glorious, not destructive. Probably, his enemies being conquered & driven away, he is just now good natured--possibly magnanimous. Yesterday was full of clouds; with gusty wins and threatened rain. But Old Sol has fairly triumphed once more, and the only result is a cooler not a dryer atmosphere. This morning the Thermometer is down to 72  F. and I presume many are complaining of cold. Yesterday it was 98 F. in the shade The day before 100 F. or more. and 97 [degree symbol} only just before sunset. It is astonishing how the hot dry weather does continue here. There has even yet been no rain to even begin to moisten the earth. I have been very busy for two or three weeks past, rather unusually so: There is quite a pile of unanswered letters lying before me; from Mother, Lucy, Eliab, Maria. Anne I have not got any letter from. To my dearest, my wife I have written since receiving any letter from her; though her last letters are really unanswered. I wrote last Sunday from Centralia. and again in the midst of the busy week, but I guess without replying to previous letters--and I am sure I cannot now tell what I wrote.

You ask, Ettie, about Abby Wilson. I have not seen her since I came back here. Her Brother has come back from California, and I guess she stays at home now. I have been intending every since I got back to go over there sometime to see Abby but somehow there has always seemed to be something else to employ me, and I have never got over there; and now we are getting on with the Truck Laying I keep my horse at Little Muddy, so I have while here no chance to ride. The Parasol I have never heard any thing of. It was not left in the room when I went back there. Mrs Keyes never said any thing about it. I told G.M. Hinckley, if Abby ever was over there to offer her V or X worth of a dress and charge it to me. Do not know whether he has done it. Oh Ettie, Dearest Ettie, it makes me glad that you want to come out here again to be here with me. I know you do want to. But, as I wrote before, think it all over, and decide understandingly that you want to come out this Fall; and I will surely find some way to get you out here, as soon as it is prudent to do so. It would not be strange after the long drouth & extreme heat of the summer if the Fall should be a very sickly one. In fact it is now already I expect in many places. There is very much more sickness than there was last year. At Little Muddy you know it was quite healthy last year. Now most of the men have got away from there--but very many of those who are left there are complaining. But we will see how it becomes, & I will try to find a good place for you at Centralia perhaps; when the sickness abates. I am sorry about your Mother's anxiety & nervousness. What about Jenny? It would do your Mother good to travel about more, and see more company than she has done. She needs good society.

"The Old Man's Home" I do not know. What Adams? is the author
The "Precious little Advocate" comes regularly. And about 20 other papers--Illinois County papers sent by R.R. Co. more than I have opportunity to read very much. You ask what Clothes I wear nowadays. Well a variety. All rather thin fabrics I assure you--various coats and pants that you never saw. One thing though--you remember those coarse crash linen pants that you and Abby I guess made last summer. Those have been really valuable to me--have worn admirably have been washed perhaps twenty times apiece--and are hardly worn out yet--and grow whiter & handsomer every time they are washed. In fact they have been all summer my best pants, though I have bought three or four other pairs this Summer. I must have more like them--They would be cheaper than ordinary Summer pants we buy, if they cost $10.00 per pair. Sometimes I wear a vest & a neck cloth, and sometimes I do not. Today being cooler I do: and a pair of linen pants white a frequent tiny brown stripe up & down. In short should be tolerably especially dressed--if--my shoes boots were blacked. The vexatious thing--the nice pretty silk handkerchief you sent me in a letter from Bangor I lost--left it in the Dining Room of Planter's House, as I left St Louis t'other day. Mr Bird got home about two weeks since--preached last Sabbath--but I did not hear him I have not seen him--Last Sabbath being at Centralia.
Is considerable trouble for me to get down there to Church now. My horses are left up to Little Muddy nowadays; Today I had to get George Smith to send his buggy & horse up here for me and then to bring me back. Rather a costly way of getting to church

Mr Bird was there apparently as fat & hearty & good natured as ever. Mrs B. however is quite unwell. Mrs Sprague I suspect is better--at any rate she was out to Meeting, though evidently feeble. Did I tell you that "Polly Ann" lived there this summer. Mr Bird did not preach but Elder Taylor, the Bible Society Agent; and after a tolerable--though rather loud--sermon, (E.T. is I believe a Methodist), upon "letting your light shine before men"", (Especially by giving them Bibles); came the Annual Meeting of the Duquoin Auxiliary Bible Society--election of Officers--same as last year--and a collection which cost this Individual Five dollars. --
By the way I believe I have not yet read my French all of it for today. Last Sunday I had no French Testament at hand Though Aspem himself loaned me a German one, (but that hardly answered) and also a course of scripture reading in French--but that contained not the lesson for the day I was so busy through the week that I only read one chapter in the whole week towards making up the Sabbath's lack. And this morning I only read one the long 7th Acts. Let us see where am I--Jean a 21 chapters. June hath 8, July 10--August 8--Last Sunday 2 The Lesson for today then is the VIII & IX Acts: Is that right by your Chronology? What time in the day do you read French. I very frequently read one chapter as I lay on my bed before rising in the morning. The other along the P.M. or after church Do you invite Mother & Lucy to visit Dunbarton this fall? I guess they talk of it. I have bought of Rowley Smith & Co. a Bedstead, Mattress Pillows etc of the best. I have found my own bed all summer on a camp cot--but it wouldn't do when the weather becomes cooler; and then I wanted something better to offer my friends. Did I tell you that I might have to go to Chicago a week on the Final Settlement with Rowley Smith & Co? 
Kisses to D.M. & Love to all especially yourself
from yr own Isaac S.

Ducoigne, Sept 17, 1854
(Isaac - 
Dunbarton Sept. 30 1854
Sabbath, Sept 17. 1854. Ducoign Ill.
Dearest Wife
Last Tuesday as I went North I received your letter of Aug. 26th--30th--and read it as I rode along on the Engine. Yesterday I received your letter of Sept. 1--5th as I came South, and read it as I rode on the Hand Car. With the last come also the Daguerrotype, for which I thank you very much. I think it is a very good one. But I though you were to get a large one. I do not believe this cost $10.00 Perhaps though you had not so much money to spare. I ought to have sent you some more before now. However this is worth more than X or XX to me.
It seems the letters are not all regular exactly--if they all arrive at last. The sometimes get misplaced in their order. Yours I believe have never come to me so, the last first; but they are sometimes delayed and two come together. You wonder Saturday night whether Charles is with me. He always is. Always in this little office out of work hours--seated in one of the high stools at the big table just behind my back as I sit at my desk. He has his bed fixed up up stairs; and lives as well as work in this building; going out only to his meals. You wonder whether I read, write, or think. Well some considerable of both each. If I have but just come in on Saturday night I have various letters, statements & reports to read; and not a little to write in arranging & finishing up the week's work. Of course too there is some thinking about tit all. --and when it is through with--I am very apt to be tired--as business man ought to be--and go to bed straight away. Here--them over

Do not take it from this last that you have any right to be tired Saturday night, or any other time. I said a business man. Any man who is paid by others for toil of muscle, or of brain, ought perhaps to be tired a little on Saturday night. In the six days which belong to somebody else--Master or Corporation--R.R. Co & its interests--he must earn his wages. But the Seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord. God's Day is given to him as a day of rest from the labors of the week; and I think it is good for this one to spend part of it in writing to his Ettie!
I have been hardly knowing what to expect on the score of that hairy picture I sent you. I am glad you do not dislike so very much as to be sorry I sent it. But I want nearly as much to know what Father says about it. I had a great mind to write you not to show it to him. You, or he himself, must write to me what is his comment upon it. I shall share before  I go East for fear if not, that I should not be admitted if he came to the door. 
You like the * in the Independent. So do I. So do everybody. --"And C." So do not I very especially; --that it not more than I do very many other things. The Daguerrotype is good--very good--for a little one. What dress is it you had on? One I never saw I guess. How do you do up your hair nowadays? Tye it up in a Ribbons, isn't it? You said Mother was writing me. I expect I will get that by the next mail. I did get a peice of Letter from Father for which I am much obliged. Now laugh at me, do! I wrote so far and opened your last letter to get the bit letter from "Father", which I had only hastily glanced over as I rode on the Rail--and behold it was

from Mother instead of from Father. Well I am equally obliged for it. Hope they will both write often You say the Thermometer at 84 F.--and rather uncomfortable. Really--it happens to be just 84 F. here today; but we do not complain at all. Some do say it is rather cold--and all are more than usually warmly dressed. Yesterday or or day before--after the sudden change of weather, I got on woolen clothes for the first time for--I do not know when. Thermometer down to 84 in the middle of the day! Till Thurs. such a think was unheard of here I think. 
There has been nor rain of any account here yet, a Shower of half an hour or so on Wednesday last they say--but not to about to much, 1 up at Centralia & above there there was a heavy rain on Monday last, and again some on Wednesday & Wed. Night. So that the Drouth is over there. Here it still rages almost unabated. 
We got letters from Lucy & Eliab yesterday. I do not know when I shall go East. I am very busy nowadays, There seems to be not much real cessation of the old ordinary business--and considerable of new; growing out of the Centralia Matters, and of the Track laying; and various running arrangements: And then the settling up and final arrangement of the Affairs of Rowley, Smith & Co. comes on; and is likely to be no small job. In the winding up of R.S & Co. affairs I may have to go to Chicago--perhaps in October. If so I may be able to go East at that time. But if I go East I want to bring back my Ettie & Mayo: And I am afraid I will have no possible place to put them. I do not know but I will have to build a house on purpose for them. There seems to be no place any where now. At Centralia or here would be the best

At Centralia there seems to be no place for any thing just now. The greatest crowding you ever saw until we can get our Big Passenger House up. Then there will be room enough for everybody. When that will be we cannot tell. We are hurrying it as fast as possible--but it is a big house & going slowly. Here there is no sort of a chance for any body to really live--except in my camp style here in the Freight House. And as for Old DuQuoin you might about as well be in New Hampshire for any way I could get there nowadays.
It is said the the Minesota & North Western R.R. Co. are preparing to dispute the right of Congress to repeal the celebrated Land Bill--on the ground I suppose that the Act once passed, Rights were vested in third parties which Congress itself had no right to take away. They'll build the road sometime--and sometime I'll have a good place there or somewhere else: but I guess we will have a resting spell a while next year. I guess it wont hurt us much either. When we haven't any thing else to do--we will take comfort. I hope Lucy will come & visit you this fall My best love to all the folks--especially to Ettie & Mayo 
Good Night
IS Metcalf

Dearest Ettie
I did have a little bit of Ague last week. No do not be troubled about it. I told Charles not to write to the folks in Maine about it, and I thought I would not write it even to you at first, and write the whole letter without mentioning it. You know how afraid all Eastern People are of the Ague, what a dreadful thing all think it; and it hardly seemed worth the while to disturb & frighten everybody, and make them think me horrible sick when I was not. But I thought it wasn't hardly right to keep even that a secret from my Ettie, even though it did not amount to anything. I would not like to have her serve me so And so I put in this Postscript. You see I made myself sick eating too many peaches last Sunday. Bought some for a dollar

a bushel on Saturday; besides eating lots of Mrs Skinners unripe Pears when I was down to Church. I was really extremely gluttonous for me. but it would all have been well enough if I could have taken care of myself. But I am lately very much pressed with business Last Week was Paytime everywhere. And I had to be every where & do every thing Mitchell being closely confined to the track. Monday I went down to Big Muddy, and was about there till Tues. Noon. very unusually exposed to fatigue--walking much--and the excessive hot Sun. Tuesday P.M. up the Line & to Little Muddy--to Wed. there & up to Richmond, similarly exposed. That afternoon not well & feverish--but must do the business & went up to Centralia that night. The next day very sudden change of weather, after rain--and I had no thick clothes there.

So very carelessly on Friday as I rode along from Centralia South, I had a nice little chill sitting quite cosily in my wagon, and after I got to Richmond a little fever to match. But I fixed up my business & came down to Little Muddy; and yesterday down here. Today took two or three doses of Quinine, and kept of the return of the unpleasant visitor.
Well it was not a tenth part as bad as the tooth ache Charles had the other day; or as bad as the head ache many a one has and thinks nothing of. But it was 'the Ague' and of course was dreadful. 
However I do not intend to have it any more at all on no count. I will be careful Ettie. 
Your own I.S.

Isaac Ducoign  Sept 24, 1854
Dumbarton Oct 5 1854                                                     Ducoign, Sept. 24 1854
My Very Dear Wife
Your nice letter of Sept. 5 -12th came
to hand on Thursday 21st; rather better time than usual.
Letters I believe are commonly longer in getting here than in
getting away.  Letters from Chicago rarely reach here in
less than ten days; while my letters usually get there
in four or five days.  Your mailing letters on Tuesday instead
of Thursday I think will make, an improvement.
My letters seem to reach you in "batches" - four in one
week!  Only half baked ones I guess mostly.
I write regularly every Sunday you know:  and 
have once or twice written something between times.
Oh Ettie, I am so glad of that Daguereotype - my own
nice sweet Ettie:  It does me good every time I
look at it, which is - sometimes.  That face and the
little one:  are my treasures.  I am rejoiced that you
have had rain.  I presume there has been rain most
every where through the country before this.  In this
region the rain has not been extended yet; or at
least, not every where.  It has seemed to come
in strips & occasionally.  There was some good rains
two weeks or more since in some places within 50
miles; but not a drop here really until last Tuesday
Then it rained finely just here for five or six hours; but
there was hardly any only six or eight miles north.
Almost none at Mt Hawkins.
You say Mayo likes some people at first sight; while he will
have nothing to do with others.  Now is his taste good, his

his judgement correct & approved in his decisions upon
the characters of people.  I think it quite an interesting
enquiry.  His likes & dislikes appear to be intuitive; now
are they well founded?  So you are really glad of 
your DuQuoin Novel Readings!  Who would have 
thought that of your father's child!   By the way how
does he like Mrs Stowe's Sunny Memories?
I have been sort of sorry ever since I last wrote
that I said anything to you about my little
bit of ague the other day.  It did not amount to
anything:  and perhaps I might not to have written
to trouble you about it.  I am as well as need to
be ever since.  It was only a natural result
of a slight indigestion and too much exposure & fatigue
after it.  I had got over it entirely when I wrote
to you before; and am better & better ever since.
I have not read much this Summer.  In fact I have
had very little leisure to read at all.  Mr Mitchells'
sickness, and then Crosby's, have made me more
than usually hurried.  Did I tell you that Crosby
had had the ague.  He gets a chill occasionally
still I believe.  had one on Friday at least; but I 
guess not very bad.  Does not seem to mind it
very much.  But it not good for much for work.
This of course makes it harder for Mitchell - and
Mitchell having hardly got as well as usual (in fact
he had one chill last week) I have to do more to
relieve him from business than I otherwise could.
I have read Cosmos but a little this Summer
Do you think it is not best to come out here this Fall.
Oh Dear!  What shall I do with myself?  I do not know

but you think wisely though
you ask if I have read certain books.  Autobiography of
Hugh Miller, I have given to Mitchell. "Hard Times" I will
send to you I think. You can read it, and decide
whether it is or not a libel upon all engineers and all
practical men.  I will hardly determine it.
We got a letter from Anne yesterday - the first since
she went East in June.  She says the Dr De Witt has
been a good deal worried about Percie because they
had no regular Physician to attend him:  and now
is very much pleased that they have called on Dr McRuen?.
I expect Eliab & Maria, are going to move into
a house he has rented farther down Centre Street
same St. as Samuels' but nearer down town.  They
wrote that Maria's Sister, whom they expected to
live with them, was quite sick.
I have been down to old DuQuoin today to Church, with
Mr Rowley.  My horses are up to Little Muddy more convenient
for me, going up to them on train.  So I used
Mr Smiths' horse & buggy.  Mr Bird preached, very well
for him.  Text "straight is the way &c.  Mr Ford grows fatter
and fatter, is really very corpulent - fussy.  He has received
a call to go to Mr Vernon Jefferson Co. to settle; and
another to Naples on the Illinois River.  I should think
he would be discouraged at DuQuion.  Congregation small.
The Bell was stolen a few weeks ago.  taken down & fairly carried
off, they know not whither!  We went to Dr Walls to dinner;
very pleasant; farewell visit of Mr Rowley who
expects to leave this part of the state this week.
We returned here between 2 & 3 P.M since then I have
written a long letter to Sister Anne.

The Doctor Wall has not yet decided where to go to.
Has been thinking to more to Jacksonville - notably
for convenience of educating his children - but I guess
decides that he cannot leave his property in this part of
to state - But can find no house to move into this 
fall.  I expect they are requested to stay & keep the
house this fall for the seminary that hardly want
to do so.  Miss Paine is coming out early in Oct.
bringing two other teachers with her.
I do not know what the prospects of the school
are - guess the great agencies have amounted 
to a few hundred dollars.
I judge Mrs Bird is better - out at Church
- Sprague worse not -
Ephraim Root is about the same - is out about some.
Did I tell you that Mrs Horace Smith had a fine Daughter
Horace you know works here, steadiest Carpenter I have seen,
his wife was at Mrs Fulton's.  Child Born on Sunday.  Horace
did not lose any time on his work!  Thomas Reeds' wife had a
Child also.  He last only half a day's time!
Mr Fulton is coming to keep our boarding house here as
soon as Mr Smith gets well.  It is now kept by Mrs Guitteau
and Josephine Fulton. who do much better than Ed. Smiths Wife.
Oh how can I stay away so much longer on
my Ettie & my baby.  It is too bad.  But take
good care of yourselves.  By the way I am afraid you live
to economically at your fathers - do not eat meat & good 
things enough.  I will send you another xx pretty soon
Have every thing you want.
Affectionately Isaac.

Ducoign. October 1st 1854

Dearest Ettie
This last week I did not get any letter
at all from you, so I have not to reply to today.  Letters
have come so regularly lately that I was quite disappointed
when none came yesterday.  The DuQuoin came
down (or rather up.  It comes down from Mt Hawkins in the 
morning; goes to the old town, and is bought back up here
before noon) and brought me no letter.  The Mt Hawkins
P.M is directed to send along every thing in Friday nights
Mail on Saturday morning.  But I thought he might have
neglected it; and so sent a messenger to the Mt Hawkins
P.O in the afternoon - but alas! he brought nothing.
Well.  I shall probably get two this week instead.
It is party a rainy day: and I have not tried to go down
to church today.  It is some ways to go to church.  I could
get along very well when the weather was not too very
hot - as long as I had my horses here.  But now, when it
is rather necessary for me to keep my horses off up
the line, it is rather inconvenient.  I do get G.J Smiths
horse & Buggy, but it is troublesome both to them & myself.
So, especially as it rains about half the time today:  I am
staid at home.  I have been reading the Independent,
about all the Forenoon - of Sept 21.  I believe
The one containing the account of the Meeting of
the American Board:  And it has really done
me a great deal of good.  It is better than anything
for a great while past.  And after the late - inaction - of the

of the great Presbyterian General Assemblies - even the New
School Assembly you remember ignoring the slavery
question altogether) it is really refreshing.
The Speeches of Drs Bacon, Dwight & others really read as if
some New England Clergymen at least were not lacking
in what Sumner called the great desideratum for a Statesman -
Backbone - Backbone - Backbone.  And after all
perhaps so much credit is not due to most of them.  They are
only driven or crowded along to their present positions by the
pressure of public opinions behind them - rather before them.
I have company today - Charles M. Dupuy - a nice fine
looking man who appeared here yesterday, with a letter
of introduction from Mr Mason, desiring me to show him every
attention, if possible spending some time with him.  He is a 
Capitalist Judge:  has been in the East India trade in N.Y City
is largely interested in Coal Mining &c.  He comes
here to examine this region, with view to establishment
of mining operations here.  He is a very pleasant comfortable
sort of a fellow who has seen something of the world and
knows how to take it.  Take a man who has lived half his
life like a prince - at the Astor House - and his bottle of wine at 
the table and everything else; and he is much more likely to
adapt himself pleasantly to any inconveniences of backwoods
life, than one - a half bred man - as most are.
Mr Dupuy  has a wife & a little boy about Mayo's age, that he
has not seen for a whole month!  Never left them so long before since
he was married, and does not mean to again.
What do you think of it?  What do you think of Ducoign at the Centre
of a great Mining region?  A great dirty smutty coal 
place- another Pittsburg - a namesake of our boy Ducoign M.!

I have been pretty busy the past week, as usual.  I believe I wrote
you about going to Ducoign to Church last Sabbath - Mr Birds sermon
his two calls - to Mr Vernon, Jerfferson Co, & to Naples D Lawton calling
at Mr Keyes', and dining at Dr Walls':  Mr Rowley's farewell
calls in the part of the state &c  Monday, here in office
Tuesday up on train.  At Little Muddy formal settlement with
Rowley Smiths & Co &c Wednesday with Rowley, Smiths, Post, Noel
and Nellis to Centralia.  Thursday separation.  Post going
after his wife, Noel Home, Smiths to Utica N.Y Rowley to Chicago.
Perhaps I shall have to go to Chicago next week, meet them
all returned there - with Mr Mason.  After which Smith
goes to Big Muddy to spend Fall & Winter.  Post probably to
Cairo, Joel to his farm.  Rowley don't know.  And I
if I only had my Ettie & Mayo, would be very comfortable
here for a few months longer.  I do want to see
my dear Ettie, and my darling boy.
Do you suppose all my land in Illinois is worth almost nothing
at all.  The last congress passed a graduation bill, reducing
the price of public lands according to the time they have been
in market.  In all the South past of Illinois (except along the R.R
line where the lands are not affected) the lands having been
in market above 30 years, are at the minimum price, only
12 half cents per acre - to the actual settler:  320 acres for $40.00
This for a week or two past has made an enormous rush at the Land
Offices.  Everybody is striving for their 160 or 320 acres of Land.
However the man who [unclear] himself for $40 worth of land, as many
doubtless do - certainly pays dear for it.  After all it may only
affect to get all the government lands sold off out of market
and out of the way, and then the other lands will soon rise.
I believe that is the view of our R.R people - who think that the
12 half of land will not permanently injure the value of things.

I shall look anxiously for letters this week
expect to get two by Saturday.  I keep thinking
that if you or Mayo are sick - But then I know
you would let me know as soon as possible.
You will take good care of yourselves for my
sake, will you not?  Ettie, Dear Ettie, I do
want to see you both - and only to think of
waiting until January - three or four months longer.
However the time is slipping away fast.
I hope Mother & Lucy will conclude
to visit Dunbarton this Fall.  You must
urge it, if you want them to come.  I have
been writing to them.  I had no letters
from Bangor written last week - am
anxiouser to hear about Percie.
Much Love

I. S.

Isaac Ducoign Oct. 22 1854

Dunbarton  Oct 31. 1854

                                                                     Ducoign. Sabbath. Oct. 22 54

M y Dearest Ettie
It is a dull rainy Sunday.
There has been post here considerable.  The Prairie
is of a dull grayish brown, and the sky or
clouds are of a dull brownish gray, in fact
pretty much alike, and both decidedly sombre.
It is most nights, but I have not done
anything yet today hardly.  Yes I have
read the Independent through Oct. 5 & 12,
which I had not before seen.  I have read three
chapters in Actes?.  I was not here last
Sabbath, and had no French Testament
to read.  I have laid down & dozed some,
and some I has sat & thought and
wished and wished to see my Ettie
and my Mayo.  I hope they are both
well & happy today.
I have been at Centralia most of the 
past week - arrived here from there on 
Monday night and went up there
again on Wednesday, returning
on Saturday night at dark.
I wrote a letter to you there last
Sunday, which was mailed perhaps
at Central City; and another on
Thursday or Friday, which was probably
mailed at St Louis.  I had occasion

occasion to send Griers in to 
St Louis on Friday
and sent it to P.O by him.
I did a little expect to find another
letter from you when I got back
here yesterday, but it seems hardly
to have had time to get around.
It is almost vexatious to have
letters so very long in coming.
To think that I do not now know
whether you and Mayo more
sick or weak and whole weeks
ago;  that it will probably be
whole weeks longer before
I shall know whether you
are sick or well at this present
time.  Does it not seem hard?
Well it will not last a great while.
And after this we will try to keep
together will we not?
I would have liked to go down
to Old Duquoin to church today;
It is sometime since I have
been there - last Sabbath I was at 
Centralia.  The Sabbath before I arrived
here from there at 3 A.M
and slept most of the day
and did not go out at all.
It is very inconvenient getting
down there to church or at any time

time now.  My horses being away
I leave them of late usually at
Richmond.  And it is too far to 
walk 4 miles; and a good deal
of inconvenience to others as
well as myself to get there.  When
I have gone down of late I have had
to get Geo. Smith to send a horse
and Buggy clear from there up
here after me.
Edwin Smith & Horace Smith have each
got a little house & moved up here.
Mrs Fulton has moved into our
boardinghouse here; and now
Mrs Mc Coy instead of Mrs Guitteau
lives with her.  Dr Ray, whom
you perhaps remember - moved to Old
DuQuoin last spring before you left
I think - bought Mr Keyes' horse & buggy
Dr Ray has moved up here.  Dr Wall
I believe talks of it - may be only
talk with him.  I guess he does
not know himself what he
will do as yet.  He talks of going
to Jacksonville to live.  And he talks
of going into wholesale mercantile
business at Ducoign station.
I have not yet heard of Miss Paine's
arrival.  I believe other teachers were
expected to come with her.  It will be most 
to bad for Mr B to have to stay there and

to stay there and keep big boarding house
all winter.  You know they undertook to move
up here the building that was  my old office
for a Methodist Seminary, but it broke down
and is left on the road.  Edwin Smith's house
was moved safely, and is now the residence
of Horace Smith & family.  Mr Keyes
is getting material on the ground
for a brick house here at Ducoign.
Charles is about deciding I think to go
home next month.  I wish I could
as I cannot have any Ettie & Baby
out here, I am getting anxious to get
to them - and yet when I get through
here I shall be out of business - I 
do not know how I shall stand it.
What shall we do?  No matter about you
and the Mayo - there is glad room enough for
you any where - but just of my being about
in everybody's wall all winter!
However I guess that won't prevent my
coming to see you as soon as
I can
Most Lovingly
I Metcalf

Ducoign Oct, 25, 1854

My Dearest Ettie
Your very excellent good letter of Oct 9th
came to hand yesterday; I had been
down & Big Muddy and got back at
noon to find the letter.  Though I might
have been sober or stupid in the forenoon
the letter of course put me in good humor
and I enjoyed the afternoon hugely
working away in the office busily, but
thinking happily of certain other people.
Today I am going to Centralia to meet
Mr Mason there tonight, and return
with him tomorrow morning.  I have
got my dinner, and got all ready
Papers all filed & packed in carpet bag
and all ready to start, and while
waiting for the train to come along I
sit down to my desk to write a bit to
my Dear Wife whom I so much want
to see; but at the same time can so much
enjoy the mere thinking of!

Our business is getting along now swimmingly -
laying more than half a mile
of track per day; going to get the track
to Centralia then about two weeks.
And work at Centralia too is prospering
up finely.  As the cool weather comes
on men are more healthy, and can
do more & better work.
Rev. Mr Wood has been here talking
and interrupting me an hour or two
this forenoon - His Presbyterian Church
is mainly gone I guess: Said there
wasn't a single male member left
He has just moved up to DuQuoin, intends
to preach at Carbondale.
Mr Bird is just now moving
to Mt Vernon.  I am glad 
for the sake he is well away
from DuQuoin.
If Mr Wood were not so entirely 
hated by DuQuoin people it would
be very convenient for him to preach 
at DuQuoin.

I hear nothing from the Seminary
at present.
I have been arguing upon Mr Wood
the importance of doing something
at Centralia - He may go there
and preach once in four weeks
this summer.  That may be
better than nothing.  But there
really ought to be some good
man there.
I would do something for
that myself.
My health is very good now.
The train is coming.
Why was I stupid yesterday?
I found the LampLighter
at DeSoto the night before
I had never really read it
and read it all night 
about.  However I feel all the
better for that since I believe
I do feel better for losing
of my sleep occasionally.

There is getting to be some brilliancy of colors in these Western forests - in fact I suppose they are very fine now as seen through the dim Autumnal Prairie haze But you know I have not a great taste for beauty of Color. Beauty of form is what I look at. And no colors are more beautiful to me than green & blue, You know I always told you next to those I prefered brown  Get a new Velvet Bonnet & everything else. I intended to put a XX in this - but find I have none except of ILL to Ind. money which might trouble you - Well I'll keep the Train waiting  Aff.  Isaac S.

Oct 29th

I wish I had a few pecks of your apples here. We do not get any good ones here this Fall. Perhaps I shall get there before they are all gone. You tell me not to work too hard. Well I have for a few days past, but I was in good condition, and it has not hurt  I sometimes think it does me good, once in a while to lose sleep, or get really tired.  I presume by tomorrow I will feel just as well as ever. I am far more afraid for Mitchell than for myself. He is worth everything to me; the most valuable man all things considered that I know of. What could I have done the past week without him. Did I tell you Mr Bird had moved to Mt Vernon, Jefferson Co. I had forgotten to tell you of Miss Paine's arrival: Came via St Louis & Centralia and down on our Train on Thursday Morning, the morning before the accident. Two other ladies

with her, perhaps equally homely. One very tall Miss Smith; the other quite short, but I forget her name. A Rev Mr Smith came with them who was to preach at DuQuoin today; Perhaps may settle there! An Eastern clergyman as I understood coming west for his health. A little boy also of their party.  What occasions your father's Diarrhea? Can it not be cured: One of those I.C.R.R. Directory here lately would give $200.000.00 freely for the power  to eat a good dinner without hurting him. He is a confirmed Dyspeptic. What good does his great wealth do him?  Oh Ettie, We are thankful, are we that our Rail Way Accident was not worse. I am thankful for Mitchell's escape, and that of our Engine Men. Their escape was almost miraculous. And then for myself how I happened not to be on the Train

If I had been I might have been killed or hurt. How providentially it all was. Then those men who were killed. With all three it seemed only accidently that they happened to be killed. But there an purpose? Then there were a lot of passengers at DeSoto wishing to come up. We were late, in great haste, and I ordered the Train run by without stopping which in all probability just saved their lives. There were two or three women & several children who would almost surely have been killed if they had got on the Train. They were very much disappointed at not going, and some of the men very angry about it.  We got an excellent letter from Lucy and Mother yesterday. Percy it seens is much better. Lucy says he eats half the time, & cries for something to eat the other half! Mr Rider is very unfortunate is he not, and then to think that

that that is probably only the beginning  Lucy & Mother seem to admire greatly the Daguereotype of little Mayo. Is it the same one you hesitated to send it nay so poor an one.
Oh Ettie the splendor of the forests here now is very great; but there is another thing to me very far superior. The Pigeons, the Pigeons! I wish I could convey to your mind my feeling of the wonder & sublimity of the miles upon sq miles. I had almost said cubic miles of Pigeons I have seen here of late. Miles & Miles positively darkened by their swift wings; and the sound. Nothing hit the waves of old ocean can equal it.  But I have written enough and perhaps more.  Love & God's blessing   Isaac S.M.

Isaac,  Ducoigne. Oct 29. 1854
Dunbarton  Nov. 8. 1854
Ducoign Perry Co. ILL  Oct. 29. 1854

 My Dearest Wife,  My Ettie. It is most eleven oclock this Sabbath morning. I have just got fairly seated but a little while; and about the first time since I can hardly tell. It has been a sad time here. We have had a dreadful Railway accident and loss of life here. Three men were instantly killed. It was just at dark Thursday night Oct 26th. Another Thomas Taylor Brakeman (whom I suppose you have seen at DuQuoin) died at 5 oclock yesterday evening. No others seriously hurt, Young Taylor is buried today,  and I should not be at the funeral, if it did not rain so very hard, and I were not already so used up & tired out. Mr Mitchell was in the most exposed situation of any one on the Train, and his  escape seems almost miraculous. He is  almost uninjured, only very lame & sore across the chest from the Shock. I believe I wrote you on Wednesday - but do not know whether I sent the letter or not  I was then waiting for our Train to go North to Meet Mr Mason. Our Engine was only order and delayed so long that I only got to Richmond at night instead of to Centralia. And met Mr Mason, with Messrs. Osborn & Griswold of N.Y. Directors of I.C.R.R. Co. at Richmond. As it happened I talked about all night with Mr Mason perhaps sleeping two hours. We all got on the Train at 5 Thursday morning, and I transferred our dignified passengers to Mr Watson's Train on the other side of Muddy at 11 A.M. The passage down was very slow but safe  The Engine working very badly on acc't of a misplaced valve. We however got their best Machinist from the first Division, and by 4 P.M. got our Engine into good working order again.

Our other old Engine had failed a week before, though I had Men in St Louis trying to repair it. So our work was very pressing for the one engine. However at 4 P.M. we were in order and started to commence our day's work. Mitchell & I both came up here to Ducoign on the Train. As it was a night Train great care requisite & absolutely necessary to be back to the River to load again before 7 the next Morning to bring up Mr Mason & his party. One or more of us would keep with the Train. I had intended to go up myself leaving Mitchell to sleep till the Train came along back: but I hardly know how it went differently, from some impulse of Mitchell's I believe, for I certainly wanted & intended to go up. But I did stay & Mitchell went on with the Train. It was then just dark. Three miles above here a cow jumped suddenly on the Track immediately before the Train, and in less probably than half a minute, that train engine & gears was one Mass of ruins. It was doubtless within 10 minutes from the time it left this station. I was soon there with lights and help  Dr Ray who lives here & other Drs sent for. Mitchell and the Men on the Engine (who were not seriously hurt) had already removed the wounded. There were 15 men on the Train. All were more or less jarred & shocked. 5 picked themselves up and went off, these were laboring men. Two others were knocked senseless but removed to a house, and soon got over it, are really unhurt  There were three on the Engine. Our Engineer & fireman jumped off and were uninjured. The other Engineman & Machiner's from the 1st Div. staid on the Engine to the last, was jammed up against the Firebox & bruised a little. It is a wonder he was not killed. If he had jumped off on the side he was on he must have been killed, though that would have been called his chance for safety. By neglecting it he was saved. The other two happened to jump just right. Thos Taylor, the Brakeman was picked up, his thigh dreadfully crushed.

and was carried off to the nearest house before I reached there.  Dr Ray
said first there was no hope for him.  The next morning he & Dr Wall
& others, thought there might be a possibility, his limb was boxed.
He was laid on my mattress, put on a car & carefully pushed
home, but died on Sat, at 5P.M Mortification taking place.
He was the only son of Old Uncle Dick" Taylor, The tall old
Backwoodsman with a hunting shirt, whom you have
seen & perhaps remember, The Old Man is a regular Western
character - The Young Man, considering his lack of advantages
a remarkably intelligent, as well as amiable fellow; universally
beloved. (Married about 2 years since to a young & delicate
girl - leaves a little child two.)
When I got there the first thing was to examine minutely all around
the wreck to see if possible there might be any injured, and
still living - but no - there were three wrecked & mangled
bodies under the wreck but they had been instantly killed.
Very probably never won knew what was the matter.  It was a 
work of considerable time & labor to raise up the broken cars with
the iron with which they were loaded so as to get them out.  It was
a dreadful sight - a merciful God preserve me from such
another.  Oh Ettie, it makes me shudder now to think of it.
When I first came up by the side of the wreck there lay in my path a 
mans boot uninjured, - but the foot & the leg were in it!  The
three bodies were all so much cracked &  disfigured it was very difficult
to recognize them.  I got them up on a car bed, composed as decently as 
possible.  Sent off for coroner & magistrates, and for the friends
of one of the men who lived 15 miles north and for Thos Taylor's family got the wounded
taken care of.  Charles to stay in charge of the bodies on the cabin.  The
Carpenters at work making Coffins; tried to get Mitchell to bed
and then started for the River.  Had to walk several miles before
I could get a hand car.  At De Soto found a Brother of one of the dead.

They were two Brothers Austin & Asahel Root who came out here a month
or two since from Vermont 18 & 21 years old, the younger went to work
at the bridge but took sick & has been unable to work most of the time
with Dysentery.  The older worked at the tracklaying, very steady one of
the very best men.  Thursday his brother sent to him to come down
and see him.  He went intending to stay a day or two but finding the
train going up at dusk suddenly concluded to go up - and was
killed.  How I pitied that boy, left alone here so far from home - entirely
destitute and sick.  I feared he would really break his heart.  But
I have got him up here & believe he is better, I will take care of him.
I got to the river before Mr Mason arrived from below.  Met him
there with the dreadful news.  Took every measure to urge
forward the completion of the bridge - so we can get Engines &
cars over from the 1st Div.  Then came up with Misters Mason Olson
& Griswold with much effort succeeded in getting them through
to the end of track by 12PM so they could go on.  I got back to the
wreck, where Mr Mitchell was already at work clearing away
the fragments with a large force of men.  The wreck is a complete
one.  Our great 10.000 engine as perfectly used up as I ever saw one,
laying lead downwards in the ditch; the machinery fairly raked and
Four Cars entirely destroyed.  The dead were buried at DuQuoin 
Old burying ground on Friday afternoon.  Austin A. Root,
Harding Keating, Jacob Randleman; all young stout
men, 20 to 25 years old, healthy & active; on the same car they
were on were four oldish men rather weak & aguish looking
who were all saved.  Friday night I got down here & by 9 slept.
I had been on my feet from 5am Thursday.  In the night
Friday, by great good fortune, Goodale got back from St Louis with
the repaired cylinder heads of the old Medford.  They went to work
on her & got her running before night Sat.  Mitchell & his men
succeeded in clearing the wreck & track.  I took all the force
I could muster to the River, worked there all day & got back
tired at 10 P.M to hear then of Taylor's death. got men at work
on coffin &c  But I finally got to sleep & slept till almost 10 this
morning.  Mitchell got the Medford started at 4 P.M up
to End of Track, came back this morning & has gone up now
3.30 P.M with another load.  I regret the Sabbath work but it seems
unavoidable.  The whole country is waiting for us 1000.00 would
not pay for the delay of a day now unless the Medford worked today.
The whole line must stop tomorrow.  The Engine working today
all can get to work tomorrow.  I never did order Sunday work.
That I could not prevent I did order not to work today at the bridge
which was taking a great responsibility - if the rain had not taken the responsibility.

John    21           June 4                                                           Isaac

Ducoign Sabbath. Nov 19 . 1854
Dearest Ettie
I believe the cold weather here comes on Sunday.
I wrote you what kind of weather it was last Sunday I believe.
Monday was as bad, the snow did not melt away until Tuesday.
After that it was quite comfortable weather.  Thursday morning
I went up to Centralia, and only returned from there on last night
Mr Mason, with Mr Watson &c and Mr M Brayman Solicitor & money for ILL
Central R.R also, came down with me: but did not stop here.  All
going down to Jonesboro to spend Sabbath.  Will probably be back here
on Monday sometimes.  Saturday it began to be cold again
and this morning everything every thing is frozen up as hard
as you please.  It was not very early when I got up & had my
breakfast this morning.  And then I found it so cold in office that I took
my writing materials and came over here to the boarding house,
and sit here by the coal fire to write.  The room is not very large, but
tolerably well filled.  There are 10 or 12 boarders who are pretty likely
to be around the fire on a morning like this.  Then the family is not
inconsiderable, and when the work is done up they are glad to come in
to sit in this room.  Perhaps I had better introduce you to the family.
I hardly know where to begin - Mrs Fulton is undeniably the head
in the kitchen:  and a very good one too.  Mrs Caroline McCoy is
probably the head in the dining room.  General Assistants, Sarah
and Josephine Fulton.  Plaything for every body Mrs McCoy's little baby,
now just beginning to go alone.  Usually on the way, Mrs Fultons
two or three boys; though I believe the oldest John divides with 
the Blacksmith Jos. McCoy the dignity of Landlord, which the latter
pretends to entirely disclaim

Your last letter, of Oct. 28th 31st was received on Tuesday last,
and has done me good all the week.  When commencing it
you seem to have just received a piece of letter from me written
at Pinckneyville.  Did I not write to you the result of the Curlee vs. Reyes trial?
The verdict, although a mixed one, various points being
considered, and variously decided, was in favor of Mr Reyes: avoiding
to Curlee less than Mr Reyes had offered him a year before.  Besides
that the interest was not allowed, which was a loss to Curlee of some
70 or 80 dolls.  You say you felt cross having a canker sore
in your mouth.  I do not believe it, that is the crossest it
was all in your imagination.  I have plagued you, and dared you to
it enough to know.  Being cross is an exploit of which you are entirely
incapable.  You had better "meekly" give up all pretentions to it.
You would I know if you could hear me snub some of these Suckers,
occasionally , so as to know by observation what Cross is.  I am
very sorry for the canker though.  Hope it is all well.  I am afraid
you and Mother do too much work, & get tired.  Why do you have
a cold?  Be careful - Hire some help in the house, if you need
it in the least.  Getting home here last night, I found letters
from Bangor, Samuel, Eliab & Lucy.  Lucy only one page though
and you know she is the news writer.  Little Charlie is there, came down
from Milo the only passenger on stage.  Coach & four all to himself!  Eliab
& Maria comfortably housekeeping & all well.  Eliab & Samuel wrote
very fully of their business.  They have got along much better than
could have been expected.  It has you know been a very hard time
for business men everywhere.  They seem to me to have been unusually
fortunate.  With such hard times in the business world; the
chances appeared decidedly against them.  Especially as Samuel's
last winter Lumber failed to come to market, and the twenty or twenty
five thousand dollars owed to Pendleton to Ross by Furber & Bradeen put it
out of the power of so 'P. & R. who were relyed upon as the backers of Furber

Furber & Metcalf, to help them at all.  All Samuels' capital
being locked up in the Furber V Bradeen lumber makes 
it out too that Furber & Metcalf are trading; entirely without any
capital - simply upon their character.  This seems to have
done very well for them.  They have done a business in six most
fact if not less than $60.000 or to a profit of probably $10.000 or 
near that. - if they can carry it through as they now hope.
A good character is the great thing.  Mercantile men are disposed to
help one another where they are secure of integrity & effort.
I did want to go to Church today.  It seems almost heathenish to live so
but I had no way to go.  Besides it is hardly understood whether
there is any preaching at old DuQuoin or not.  Mr Bird was coming
back sometimes to preach a farewell sermon:  it may be Today.
The New Minister Mr Smith who is to come, will preach half of the
time here at the station.  While they were trying to subscribe for 
it at old DuQuoin:  they asked G. J. Smith to try to get a subscription
at the station, if Rev Mr Smith was to preach there part of the time
G.J.S answered, "Never mind the subscription, I will be personally
responsible for one half of the salary, if it cannot be raised with out at
"the station" this point will soon raise a Ministers' whole salary,
and not half of it only.  Oh!  I have not told you how
S.M Ashley - former Engineer of 1st Div I.L.R.R. has
bought a large farm (L. Drys') near this station, and
is going into the coal business here.  His family
came up here Thursday; and are new at Roots.
They will probably live here permanently.  Mrs Ashley
& Mary are in good health.  Mrs Ashley though looks 10 or near
20 years older than she did two or three years ago.  She has
another child, four months old - born in Kentucky.
I have hardly seen Mr Ashley yet, and do not know
whether he designs building here immedially or not.

Oh Ettie!  My Ettie!  I am going to see my Ettie &
my Mayo!  I have got most through here; and then
Our track laying on this Division was completed last
night Nov. 18th that is the straight line was connected
through to the track from the North.  There are
still side tracks, from out & to lay at Centralia.
In a few days Regular Passenger Trains will be running
over the Road - carrying passengers from Cairo
by way of the Ohio Mississippi R.R. to St Louis.
I have various things, of arrangements of buildings,
Water Stations &c to finish up;  but I mean to do it all
pretty fast & quick, and get away in a month
or so. - and then I will go to see my Ettie
and my Mayo.  Take good care of yourself
- both yourselves, till that time - Then I'll
come & take care of you.  Be careful as the cold
weather comes on - remember, you have been two winters
in a hot country where there
is not much winter.  And you will feel the
cold weather - Be especially provided with alum
and best winter clothing - Buy it ready made
and not try to sew for it.  You can just as well Underclothing,
as well as outside - Do my Ettie.
And yet on acct of cold, do not neglect being out of doors
you & Mayo both - not feel the cold - but most abundantly
provide first furs - furs &c.  But at any rate & above all
do not be cold - do always, hurts' any one to be cold.
Your own Isaac

De Soto. Nov. 24th 1854

My Dearest
I believe I must write a little to you tonight.
Yesterday I was made glad by two excellent letters from
your own dear self.  One was mailed at Dunbarton
Nov. 7th, The other at Concord on your way to Pembroke
Nov 9th.  How much good they have done me
ever since.  They seem to keep me in heart like
a good meal of victuals.  It has been rather a 
busy week.  I spent the Sabbath at Ducoign:  writing a 
letter there to you & another or two to Bangor, which
I expect were mailed at Chicago by Mr Post, who started from
this region for there on Monday.  Monday I was up at Centralia.
Track had been completed on Sec Div. before that.  On Monday
it was connected through with that laid alone making
a connection with the Ohio & Mississippi R.R. to St. Louis.
On Wednesday commenced regular trains, running
through for passengers each way.  St Louis at 9 A.M
Sandoval (the crossing of O.D.M & I.L.R.Rs at 11.30, Centralia 12 P.M
Ducoign 1-40, Cairo 5-30 P.M
Cairo 6 A.M Ducoign 10-50, Centralia 12-30
Sandoval 1-30 St Louis 4.  All are to stop to
Dine at Centralia - but unfortunately as yet there is
no place to dine;  and passengers are fortunate if
they are not compelled to go through fasting.

I came down here Wednesday P.M. to hurry up some Lumber. Went to Centralia Thursday; with a fine rain; And today down here again. Tomorrow I think I shall only go back as far as Ducoign and spend the Sabbath there. 
You seem, by your letters, to be very busy nowadays You must be careful about doing too much, and fatiguing yourself too much. You and Mother all alone doing all your work. Do not be too smart. Reading the first letter I was quite sorry for you being disappointed about going to Pembroke to Examination. But when I came to read the other, it told of better weather, and that you had already started. I hope you had a pleasant time; and have ere this written me a full account of it. I suppose George came home with you, and you are now having a nice pleasant time together. I wish I were there too. Never mind, I expect to be by and by. Yes, and then will not some of us be glad! Will Little Mayo be afraid of me? He would, I expect if I should come home with the whiskers! By the way, I have not been to St Louis lately, Given (who you know was our Barber) has been sick, and all busy; and the beard & Moustache has all grown rather long. If I do not wear the hair East I shall have to send you another Daguereotype!

You enquire whether I hear from Anna. Well I haven't at all since I told you about long time ago; till yesterday, when with yours arrived a long nice letter from Anna, who was all well & very happy but very busy all the time. Has I guess a good deal of company. Their Son Dr. Wees from Illinois has been making a visit there with his family; whom Anna likes very well. She mentioned receiving your letter. I hardly know yet whether to bring trunks & c when I go east or not. Probably I will though mostly. I cannot tell yet when it will be.  I have a good many things to attend to yet to finish up my business. Crosby has got about through. I hardly know whether he will go home or not. Mitchell you know stays here as Road Master. Given will probably be a conductor on the Road. Mr Keyes intends to build & live at the Ducoign Station as soon as possible. 
Really, an extensive purchase of books "The Lady of the Lake", Pocket edition I presume, price .25. and the only book you have bought in six months?
