Your last letter, written just before you were going to Pembroke was written when you had just heard of our R.R. Accident here of the 26th ult. Now do not go and worry about it all at once, as if I were in danger, simply because I am employed on Rail Roads. Besides the kind care of an over ruling Providence; you know I claim to be a very careful man, especially of myself & mine; and moreover

and moreover that I am in a very safe business. At any rate do not worry about me. My health is excellent nowadays. The cold weather braces me up--after the heats of the Summer; and I am very well. So is most every body else now. Little Charlie Dunning is thought to be getting better. His father has been very sick is probably recovering now. I have a business letter or two to write this evening. Good night and kisses to Ettie & Mayo
Isaac S.
Mrs I.S. Metcalf 
Dunbarton, N.H.

Ducoign Dec. 3, 1854. (Isaac)
Dunbarton Dec 12. 1854--
Ducoign, Sabbath Dec. 3 1854
My Dearest
I did not get any mail last week all the week long, until I got here on Saturday afternoon, near night, Then the Ducoign Mail was here in large amount; lots of newspapers etc but the rascally Mt Hawkins Post Master had not sent along the Mail from that office. So I started a messenger immediately after it; and by about Seven o clock had the gratification of receiving two most excellent letters from your own dear self. 
One was mailed Nov. 14, one Nov. 21st; just a week apart in starting, but reaching me the same day. The first was commenced Nov. 12, just 20 days in reaching me. So you did not go to Pembroke after all; only got as far as Concord. Well, you had a pleasant ride, and that is one good thing. The DuQuoin people have not yet got a preacher. They have given a call to the Rev. Albert Smith late of Peru, formerly I believe of Middlebury College, but it is doubtful as yet whether he accepts it. The People got up a Subscription to raise 250. The Home Missionary Soc. to pay the other 250. of a 500 Salary. The Old Town was to raise 125. & the New 125. But I guess that both have done, or intend to do better still than that
Mr Smith was down here, came with the D.F. Seminary Teachers, and preached I think two Sabbaths; and they sent the call on to Peru after him. He had expressed a wish to move down here on account of his health, and partly bargained for Geo. S. Smiths' place at Old DuQuoin. The Seminary they say is prospering--that is Miss Paine & another Teacher I

have a School of some 20 or more females. One of the Ladies who came on with Miss Smith is teaching a School up here at the Station. 
Mr Bird is coming back sometime to preach a Farewell Sermon at DuQuoin. It was to have been last Sabbath but he did not come. Thursday last, Thanksgiving day, Mr Wood preached there. I had an express invitation from Elders Sprague & Hinckley to come down and read a Sermon instead (You know Mr Wood is extremely unpopular with DuQuoin people) I did not be able to go there; and had no thanksgiving at all, except to occasionally think of my Ettie & my Mayo. Working & writing all day.
So poor little Mayo has to go to bed all alone in the dark. Isn't he "too little"? I suppose though it is doubtless best for him. Bring him up in the way he should go. You ask if Mr Mason isn't on the Line often these day's. Yes, he is in the south part of the State considerable part of the time. You know it is easier getting about through than it was There is now only 20 Miles of Track lacking to make the connection through to LaSalle. There is about one hundred & twenty miles of Road in running operation here; and of course the Chief must attend to it. Mr Mason was down here this last week, yesterday and day before. Big Muddy Bridge is done--the wood work--the stone work is not entirely complete, & John Condit Smith is at work upon it. But Trains have run over it regularly since Nov. 1st. Little Muddy Bridge you know is of stone entirely--stone arches. It was finished so track was laid over it, and it has been

regularly used since the first of October middle of September. At the same time the Bridge is not complete, the coping, or ornamental top courses of cut stone are not put on completely . It is currently affirmed that Mistress Keyes declares particularly that whatever any body else may do, she shall never live at the Station. Mr Keyes is preparing for a residence here as rapidly as possible. In fact he is here all the time now; frequently does not go down to the old town for more than a week together. Appears, if as if he had no care at all for his family. I have not seen Mrs Keyes for several months. I have seen Abby Wilson lately for the first time since you were here. She said she was going to write to you Should before, but did not know where to direct. Is your bonnet black? I know I shall like one side of it at any rate. Why do you not get yourself some furs if they are worn? I cannot tell yet when I shall get away, and go home. Mr Mason said long ago Dec. 1st; but I did not expect it and wrote you Jan. so that you need not expect me too soon. Still I may get away before the month of Dec. is out. At any rate you know, its will be as soon as I can. I am much obliged for Mother's few lines in yr letter. Mayo is really backward about his teeth. Only five yet. Mrs McCory's baby, several months younger, and who does not go alone yet, has a whole mouth full, some 14 or 18 I believe she told me. So you have already begun to catechise little Mayo upon meekness! I expect you will find though that he has

got too much of his father about him to excel in it quite as much as his mother. It is a little curious though hardly to be wondered at I suppose that he should reply, when asked "who was the meekest," in sounds much more rambling "Mama" than "Moses"!
Charles has not yet started will probably go this week sometime--he did almost start last week but I persuaded him to stay. 
Les Confidences de Alph. Lamartine is not much good, is it? You do not ought to do so much work and get so tired either of you. And to prove it to you got a bad cold, and were about sick--there is nothing like getting tired to give one a bad cold. And poor little Mayo too with a bad cold--I suppose by running about on the wet floors when you were washing. Can yo not get somebody else to wash for you. And how did you get along as Editress of the Paper with such a bad cold and half sick? I shall be home petty soon to take care of you you will find--possibly (not probably) by Christmas. Do take care of yourself--will you not my dearest? I believe I have sent you three X or lately, I will put another in this letter I guess--make XXXX No late letters from Bangor, Charles got a bit of one from Anne--and two from Milo yesterday. But do not stop writing to me as Albina did to Charles!  Kisses to Mayo, and love to all--but especially to mine Ettie,
Most Sincerely I.S. Metcalf

Sabbath, Dec 16. 1854
Ducoign P.H
My Dearest Dear Wife Ettie

                                    I did not get any letter

from you all the week long.  I was
quite disappointed when I got here from
Centralia last night not to find any.
I am a little disposed to attribute the
blame to the rascally post master at
Mt Hawkins.  It is possible there may
be a letter there, though I hardly see
how it could be left there.  The mails
however may be detained some
other way, and the scamp may
be innocent - that is - in that
particular.  Really I do not hardly
know how to keep Sabbath without
a letter from you.  However I have
today as Independent & a Congregationalist, 
& a Chicago Evangelist.
I did think last night that I would
go down to DuQuoin today to
see if there were any meeting
there - I know there is no minister
- but - when I got up this morning -
not very early - and there was
no possible way to get down

there but to walk the four miles and back, it seemed rather too great an undertaking; especially as it was very cloudy, and seemed like to rain, which too made the prospect for any meeting at all, when I did get there, very small However, it has not rained any as yet and I have almost been sorry I did not try it; for really it is a long while since I have been to Church at all. 
But here have I sat and read all day so far, and Mm Crosby by me. Charles started last Thursday, and it really seems very lonesome here without him. I wrote you last from here last Sunday Monday I went to Centralia, Tuesday back here Thursday to Centralia again with Charles on his way East. Yesterday back here again. Charles I suppose is today in Elyria. And about next Wednesday or Thursday will be at Bangor. 
When I have just--stopping this letter--written a letter to Charles to get home to Milo, about as soon as he does. 
When I shall get away I cannot say

I met Mr  Mason at Centralia yesterday morning. He is to be down again on Tuesday 26th, and very possibly I shall get away immediately thereafter. Then may have have to stop a week or so, some days at least in Chicago; and then Mr Mason spoke as if he might wish me to go to "Our folks" in New York City. But you may be sure I shall lose little time getting away to my Ettie. I have got pretty much tired of every thing else. You see by this letter I have got too lazy to even write decently! You see I keep Crosby as a Copyist for me lately, and so hardly try to write sometimes! There, a poor excuse is better than none, I have heard but this is too poor even for that! 
What shall we do this winter when I do get there? I suppose you do not want to go down to Bangor near as much as I do. I must go there a while; I want to see how Eliab & Samuel are getting along, and try to help them out of their difficulties if possible. Charles had $950. or more of his money when he started. I almost ought to have sent some to them by him; but in fact the "financial crisis" was so great here that I could not very well do so. I had paid

out too much of my own money, and it was hard getting it again. It is really very hard times for Rail Roads nowadays. Mr Mason talks encouragingly of of Minnesota next Spring. What do you think about it? Has not Jenny got enough of Factory to want to come home & stay with Father & Mother contentedly? --she will while you & are are gone down East this winter, will she not? 
DC Mayo
When you get this letter, perhaps you had better write to Elyria, ere to Anne rather than here--for by that time it will be too late for a letter to find me here, and I shall go through Elyria on my way Home. And I shall want to hear from you especially if I have to go to N.Y. City, and stop a while--as is very possible
Love to all, especially Ettie & Mayo
Your own
IS Metcalf

Issac, Chicago Dec. 31, 1854
Dunbarton Jan 4. '55
Chicago, Sabbath. Dec. 31st 1854
My Dearest Ettie
I believe I must write a letter to you, even though I knew I should leave it behind me in getting to Dunbarton. I do so much want to hear from you & Mayo today. I was very much afraid from what you wrote that Mayo was going to be sick. That was by letters I received a week ago yesterday. I got another a bit of a letter in pencil written the 20th I believe, which came to hand last Wednesday (written to tell one how much money you had received) from which (as you did not mention his being unwell) I judged that Mayo must be in health. I shall very much hope to find a letter from you at Elyria. I cannot tell when I shall get there exactly. I am hoping to get through here tomorrow possibly in season to start in the Night Train East tomorrow night: in which case I would get to Elyria Tuesday night, and possibly to Dunbarton by Saturday night. You must not however be surprised or alarmed if I do not get there for a week longer. There is no knowing what delays I may meet with.
I wrote to you last Sabbath from Ducoign. Monday I went up to Centralia. Staid there

there until Wednesday, then down to DuCoign. Thursday noon started north with Mr Mason who came down on Wednesday, and started back with me on Thursday. That night we stopped at Vandalia with Mr Jones Eng. 3 Div. The next day Friday the last of the Track was laid on the 3 Div. thus making a connection through from Cairo North. Regular Trains will not commence through though until Jan. 8th Much of the 3 Div. Track is in bad order and needs considerable work to make it fit to run over safely. Mr Mason complimented my Second Division work considerable, at the expense of Mr Jones! Friday night we stopped at Decatur with Mr Plant. H.B. Plant Eng. 4th Div. I had never met Mr Plant before; He is quite a young man, really good looking; and I liked  him considerably. Saturday we came here; via Bloomington, LaSalle, Meneola & Aurora. I may be fortunate enough to get away from here tomorrow night or Tuesday morning, but may not. This Forenoon I went to the Plymouth Church; and heard Mr Eggleston preach It was a sermon to Children on New Year's time, upon the Youth of Christ. I noticed Mr Broad whom you remember coming to DuQuoin as Chorister, & singing powerfully!

This evening I believe I shall go to hear Mr Patterson, Mr Rowley's Minister, whom you have heard him speak of so much. At the 2d Presbyterian Church; the finest in Town. He is to preach a special Sermon for the New Year's occasion. I was a good mind to not go for Mr Rowley pays it is no credit to Mr Patterson to preach a good sermon; for he cannot help it! Mr Rowley I saw last night in a few minutes after I reached here Ettie, I gave your Rocking Chair to Mrs Ashley was that proper." I could not carry it way Mrs Ashley at the Station one day happening to sit down in that Chair admired it much and so I gave it to her, the day I left there. 
I got a letter from Charles before I left Ducoign, written at Elyria on his his way home. He had got a bad cold by that time. I knew he would in travelling. Few can travel in winter without. I guess it is about time for Church and I must stop writing 
Truly Etties'
IS Metcalf

Isaac  Lewistown Penn.
  June 8, 1855
Bangor June 14, 1855                                                                      Lewistown  Mifflin Co. Penn
                                                                                                        Friday Eve. June 8 1855

Dearest Ettie
I  couldn't go through this country
without seeing it by daylight, and
so stop here tonight.  Were you ever in New Hampshire?
Perhaps you thought there
were mountains there.  Well it proves
to be a mistake!  The mountains are here.
I never saw so much in my life - and I 
have not got through the Alleghanies yet.
You know I care nothing for the beauty
of color which you admire so much - skies blue & red,
tinted leaves &c, But I do believe
that I have an eye & a taste for beauty
of form - and variety of form as its beauty in
mountain.  These mountains  too are now my
favorite color - green all shades of it, and
all reflections too, in sun shines & shade &
cloud shadow  But I must tell you
of my progress & journey.  I left Boston by
Providence R.R at 5.30 P.M after loafing most
of the day in Boston yesterday.  Visited Public
Garden & Greenhouses, and saw lots of flowers
which you would have admired more than I.
In the Garden the White Iris seemed to be universal

The Great Train stopping the duet made R.R Travelling
very pleasant, and I almost wished I had
gone through by R.R especially there reaching
Stonington the wind seemed to be heavy.
But I went on board the fine steamed C. Vanderbelt
at 9 P.M and slept excellently til 6 the next 
this morning, when I found us just coming
in sight of N York via East River.
Had time in New York to get Breakfast & tickets, and
to see the outside of Garrisons Museum, now resplendent
with the great Baby Show.
Left N.Y at 8 by the Camden & Amboy to Phila
90 miles by 12,0 clock.  Had not time in Phila
to see much, leaving there at 1P.M.
First through the beautiful Chester Co. Valley
the land of milk & butter. - to Lancaster
and old Dutch City incorporated 40 years ago
nearly, and apparently having slept ever since
till lately.  30 miles farther come down onto the
valley of the Susquehanna, broad & beautiful
both valley & river, with wide current & green
islands. - Lambert Canal boats besides
then Harrisburg, and then crossing the great
Susquehanna bridge 3/4 mile long - and the 
mountains - the mountains - all sorts of
mountains, and all sorts of gaps, 60 miles
to this place which is next of the Blue Ridge.

The Alleghanies are yet to come.
Through the mountains from the Susquehanna
here 40 miles the road follows the Juniata River
Juniatas? beautiful streams. I suppose the same
one where rosed bright Alfarata, but probably
on account of the late great rain its waters
are by no means blue - but exceptionally muddy.
This pleasant little shire town of Mifflin Co, Lewistown
was once the residence of Logan
the Mingo Chief, famous Indian Orator.
Well perhaps I have written more than you
will have patience to read.
I do not know when I shall reach Elyria
I am thinking some of going right down
the Ohio River from Pittsburg to Cairo.
It will be some cheaper, and then I
should not see Elyria till after going 
to Chicago.  An objection to this is that
I want to hear from Ettie & Mayo.
At any rate you had better write to 
DuQuoin, as soon as you get this.
I shall write to Ann, if I do not go right there
from Pittsburg or Brookville.
Sincerely
Isaac

Isaac  Curwensville Penn                                          221     187

  June 10, 1855                                                        166     132    

Bangor June 16, 1855                                                 55      55
"Good Intent & People's Line Hotel"
Curwensville, Clearfield Co. Penn.
Sabbath, June 10, 1855
My Dearest Wife

 If my letters should ever all get to you, I guess they will be considered 'abundant'  I have written about once a day since leaving Bangor I believe! Bangor June 6, I wrote from Boston the 7   from Lewistown Penn the 8th, Last eve being Sat. eve. I put off writing till today. However as I am am going farther & farther away, perhaps the letters will arrive 'scattering'. I believe I have written you a pretty full account of my journeyings until yesterday.   Yesterday morning, June 9th I first lost my nice new French umbrella which cost $2.00 Now do not begin to say it was 'just like me.' & to wish I would not do so: for it really was not my fault but the Landlord's who lent it to another, and if I had time, or it would have paid to stop for it, I would have made him pay for it. Perhaps though he will send it in to Pittsburg to me. After this trifling 'Episode'  I took the cars and rode 55 miles among the Mountains & the Juniata River River - through some of the mountains in fact, to Tyrone among or under the Bald Eagle Mountains  The day before the Blue Ridge Mountains were all green of various shades. These today, nearer the Alleghanies, are only green partly; Much of the say being only Limestone, either  great perpendicular cliffs & edges, or immense piles & slopes of  the fragments thereof.

At Tyrone at 8 oclock I took Stage and about 12 or 13 hours pretty steady riding to reach this point 42 miles or perhaps only 40.  Tyrone City is a new place springing up on the Rail Road, but in the midst of an old Iron Mining & Blasting region, the Tyrone, Union Birmingham & Bald Eagle Furnaces being having been in operation for 30 or 40 years at least.  From Tyrone City to Bald Eagle Furnace is a gently ascending Plank Road - then come the Alleghany Mountain itself, the great Back Bone of this part of the world. First up a long hill and down a short one two or three times, and then up, up, up - winding along the mountain sides, on a turnpike road cut out of the rocky slopes, but always up, up  3 miles, which I walked, to the Summit, the t op of the Alleghany ridge. The Mountain is beautiful with flowers of various kinds especially flowering shrubs.

In the afternoon over the hills to Clearfield on
the Susquehanna, near the mouth of the large Clearfield Creek.
Clearfield is quite a large village.  The shore tour
of Clearfield Co, perhaps about as large as Dover & Foxcroft,
and apparently about 100 years old.  But those who turn
the world upside down, (the 'Yankees',) have come hither also,
Clearfield is quite a Lumber region; and in the midst of 
Lumber, coal & iron is declined soon to have Railroads
and be something.  It is quite an invasion though
that of the Yankees into there Sleepy Hollow regions
of Pennsylvania Dutchland.
This Place - Connersville (Cervinsalle on the maps)
(Kirwansville I should call it) 6 (six miles up the Susquehannah
from Clearfield is much like that, only
smaller.  Here the stage lays over till Monday.
So I shall regularly reach Brookville on Monday 
night.  I did not write that it rained some
yesterday afternoon, though I was very comfortable on
the stage top - rain hard before we reached here, and
very hard all night & this morning; but seems
now.  10 A M to be clearing away.
I enquire for meeting, but they say nicht
but some kind of methodical preachment this evening.
12PM An hour or two since I saw children in the street, and
going out found a Methodist Sabbath School of 60 or 70
scholars, but all little ones, almost an infant school: a large
part only learning to read.  There is also a little Baptist
Meeting house here, but no meeting in either.
I should hardly know what to do, if I had not here
a little pocket Testament that Ettie gave me.

I may get tired of staying here, and the noise
of the adjacent Bar room, where the Maine Liquor
Law does not seem to have reached; and
conclude this afternoon to take to the mountains,
and walk towards the next town.
Oh Ettie - how much I have wanted another
pair of eyes to see these mountains and everything
with for two days past.  That seemed
to be the only thing lacking in my enjoyment
of them.
Tell Samuel & Eliab that these great trains all over
the country, are bringing every thing in the shape
of Lumber & Timber in to markets, more than
ever before, and the prices are going down
to nothing almost.  All the Lumber
Operators in this region are losing about
every thing.
I shall mail this to Bangor, but the next
time I write I had probably best direct
to Milo.  Write all about Mayo, as well
as yourself
Isaac S.

Isaac - Elyria Ohio June 18 1855                                                      Elyria Lorain Co. Ohio

Milo June 25 1855                                                                            Sabbath, June 17, 1855
My Dear Wife Ettie
Here arrived I safely last night, and
found your nice letter of June 8th, and here I am
longing exceedingly for one of later date.  This was written
before receiving any of mine, and I wrote to you almost every day.
I wrote to you on the 7th at Boston, the 8th at Lewistown Penns
mailed at Tyrone on the 9th, again on the 10th at Curwensville Penn.
which was mailed at Luthersburg the 11th; and again at Brookville
Jefferson Co. Penn. mailed there perhaps the 13th.
I left Brookville Thursday night June 14th and rode by stage
to Clarion, capital of Clarion Co. about 20 miles, slept two or
three hours, and started again at 4am by stage for Calfish.
I travelled stage in Penn from Tyrone in Blair Co. North West
100 miles through Centre, Clearfield, Jefferson & Clarion Counties,
At Clarion I turned S.W towards Pittsburg,
Fifteen miles from Clairon I found the Alleghany River
at Brady's Bend, at the Great Iron works of that name.
I was at Brady's Bend most of the day waiting for a Steamboat.
It is a curious place - let me make you a diagram of the
course of the river. 
[[diagram of river with Brady's Bend on left, Cedarbank Creek
on right, Red Bank in middle]]
From Calfish to Redbank is 10 miles
by the River:  by land 1/2 mile!
From the Highway I came on one looks down upon the beautiful winding River
and the little landing places, apparently right under feet.  They seem
much farther away vertically than horizontally!  The hills which
every where shut in the Alleghany River in this region must be
more than 500 feet high.
At Bradys' Bend are by far the largest Iron Works I have ever
seen.  There are about 40 Puddling stacks, and great Rolling
Mills for Rail Road Iron making.

It is the best chance for Iron manufacture I have ever seen.
The Bluff rising every where behind the works seems to be made
on purpose of alternate layers of the best of Iron Ore, Coal, and
Limestone, - Everything they want for the Iron manufacture.
And yet there those great works, everything in perfect
order, have been lying entirely idle these five months.
There are about 50 boarding houses for workmen, besides those
for superintendents - offices &c &c.
I staid at Brady's Bend most of the day, looked at the works, the
Railways to bring down coal & ore, &c &c  The came up
the little steamer  Car n Planter, on which I took passage
went up as far as Calfish five miles, and then down
among the hills of the wild beautiful Alleghany; hills
much of the way in all their original wildness, but get frequently
pierced by the smutty coal mine, or obscured by the black
smoke of the Iron Furnace, or the vapors of the salt works.
All these are abundant.  There seems to be but one thing
lacking in this region - that is for its manufacturing
interests - that is a little water in the river - The Alleghany is
like the Ohio, only more so - of which John Randolph
said it was froze up one half of the year, and dried up
the other half.  There are really but a few weeks in
the year that it is fairly navigable; As long it rains
all the time it is a beautiful river indeed but a few warm
days dry it up.  When I was on it it had not rained for
a day or two, and they called that about the last day
the boats could get up - though we met a couple
going up or trying to that night.  but of this soon 
extends there, it must keep it up a few days longer.
The corn planter reached Pittsburgh in the night.
I had the next morning till 8 o Clock to look about

about in Pittsburgh--the city of Iron & Coal Smoke. The Iron City, it is called. Iron & Iron manufacture are the principal to be seen. But the everduring? Coal smudge is always on hand to prevent anything being fairly seen. By the way I found my umbrella tolerably safe, by express from the Land Lord at Lewiston where I lost it.
I left Pittsburgh at 8 A.M. by R.R. for Cleaveland. Arrived there at 3 three P.M. waited there till 3 1/4 and reached Elyria at 7 P.M. in the midst of much rain but in fine health & spirits, and found all here about the same. They had been expecting to see me for a day or two. Everything here is nice comfortable & convenient, as can be. Do you not wish poor you & I & Mayo & Grace! had some nice place of our own? Would not we be  happy? However, I guess we will not complain much. We have much now to be grateful for. Probably we are as happy now as most people usually are,--at least when we can keep together.
This house is improved very much since you were here. They have a boarder a Miss Smith of Westfield the Teacher, an old friend of Anna's. I do not know as I can write any thing now about the folks here. They want to see you and Mother probably more than they wanted to see me. They had a great freshet here a week ago, carried away mills, bridges etc. and now is another great rain. It rained

rained hard all night I believe, and the same about all day. But we all went to Church - Rev Mr Wilburn their Minister--I believe you saw him did you not? A sandy red headed young man is quite a fine preacher.
I hope another letter from you tomorrow morning. I do not know yet whether I shall go on to Chicago tomorrow night or wait a day or so.
I did really want to go down the Ohio River. I believe nothing hindered me from it but the desire of getting here a letter from you. I believe I directed my last to Milo. Guess I will send this to Bangor for I hardly believe you have gone there yet--have you? I mailed at Pittsburgh a letter to Furber & Metcalf containing plans of their land etc. etc. I want to hear how Eliab made out at Boston that week. I suppose I need not ask you to kiss Mayo for me. Please Lucy too. I did not think I should not see her again before I left. 
on right side:
Special congratulations upon the new shawl much as I admired the yellow one.
Yours only & ever
Isaac S
(Be careful of my Ettie) Do not sew so. Love to All

Isaac, Brookville Penn. June 14 1855
Milo, June 25, 1855
Brookville, Jefferson Co. Penn.
Thursday, June 14, 1855
My Dearest
Why I have not written to you for a great while, since last Sabbath I guess. Yes I wrote on Sunday at Curwensville, Clearfield Co. and mailed the letter at Luthersburg on Monday. Well I got tired enough of a Sabbath at Curwensville--There was no meeting--the Town was full of the Susquehanna River Raftsmen, who were noisy etc. and after Dinner I took to the roads on foot, climbing the finest of hills covered with Locust Trees in full bloom, much of the way. 
I came to where there had been a meeting preaching by a Moravian, United Brethren, meeting just through, & I wished I had started a little sooner. 
About that time it began to rain, and I stopped at a comfortable wayside Tavern. Monday 11th I walked on before the stage got along, through Luthersburg, and some 12 miles I guess. Finally the stage, and got here at night 3 days from Tyrone. Tuesday & most part of yesterday I spent in the woods walking all the time over the hills and through the Laurel swamps, and did not tire me much either. This Mountain air is very

and exhilarating; I have felt stronger and better than for a long time. I can now walk all day in the woods without fatigue, which I could not have done by any means a few weeks since. 
This Village is a straggling affair, along the hill sides at the union of two or three smaller creeks which from the Red Bank branch of the Alleghany River. It is not so large as old Clearfield on the Susquehanna, but has much more business I judge. 
I think I shall leave here tonight--Go by stage to Clarion, the shire town of Clarion Co. --thence to __at the mouth of the Red Bank, and thence by Steamboat to Pittsburg. I rather want to go right down the Ohio--Clear to Cairo--and may conclude to do so. It will be very much cheaper than any other way I could go, and I want to see the whole Ohio River. But on the other hand, I want to hear from my Ettie & Mayo, and when I get to Pittsburgh tomorrow night or Saturday morning, the temptation may be too strong for me to go to Elyria to stay over Sunday, and find a letter or two there.

Well I do not know what more I have to write. I suppose you are rather tired of my pertinacious urging you not to sew, Sew so. 
And I expect before this reaches you you will be at Milo, and I believe you promised me when you got there you would not sew any more hardly--but run about outdoors with Mayo. Do not now sit right down, and sit, sit, and sew, sew, all the time. --Neither try to take long walks and tire your self all out. You will Ettie I know be good about it, won't you?
I shall send this to Milo I believe
Most affectionately 
I.S.--
This writing is horrible but the pen is very bad. And the ink the same. I forgot to take an inkstand.

My Ettie--Sometimes when I stop & think I am much at a loss what to do with myself. If there were not two or three things--or persons--which make life so beautiful to me, & the enjoyment of life while I live, so much an object to me, probably I should be plunging into business wherever I could find it, going south, or going any where where my profession, and my advancement in it, might call me. But as it is, I hesitate; I think not only of my profession, not only of myself alone. The happiness, the comfort, the health, the best interests, of others are still dearer to me. A home--A home, for myself and those so dear to me, rises before my mind, as the great object of desire. I had hardly thought of a permanent home for myself until within a year or two or three--Now it seems the one great object of my thoughts. But where shall it be? That is the great question. And it is a hard question for me to settle. The decision of it belongs as much to you Ettie as to me. It is for you and I and our children. If I had business of any kind there I should like to live in Bangor, surrounded by so large a proportion of those who are dear to me. But we are not able to live without business, neither could I be permanently happy to do so.

We could settle down on a N.E. Farm--on N.H. hills or in Maine forests. We have the means to do it on a small scale, away from the larger Towns, but still with some N.E. priveliges for ourselves & ours, besides its bracing air. We could be healthy & happy; but humble, and always when noting the growth of prosperity of this mighty West, we should remember that we might have been a part of its growth & greatness. We might perhaps do better among the hills of Pennsylvania, equally healthy, more fertile, more chance for material prosperity, but less for moral & social advantages. 
Then Ohio, where we could be fully equal to N.E. in Moral & social privelege--fully equal to the land of Penn. in the chance for material prosperity, but without the bracing health giving air of either Penn. or New England. Then the fertile plains of Illinois; We might locate here as healthy probably as in Ohio, with still greater prospects of material prosperity--with the prospect almost sure of Wealth before us--after a few years of effort--here we might not live to enjoy it--and for social & other priviliges, apart from our own fireside--alas these would all be only in the brilliant promises of the future--What say you to it? Where shall we look for our home?

Or shall we look farther?
The high rolling prairies of Kansas--hilly prairies--at the head water of great rivers, are laid by some to be by far the healthiest & the most fertile portion of the whole continent, and one day to become a seat of its richest civilization. Shall we go there? Perhaps--when I help build a Pacific R.R. through there. --
On the other hand there is Minnesota--which seems now the great El Dorado of New Englanders. By the way, I have just seen in the streets here a Goffstown man, Houston--I believe--just from St Paul's. He is in perfect extacies with Minnesota, cannot find words for his admiration of the climate, the soil, the rolling hills, the crystal lakes, the gushing springs, etc. etc. All are perfect. And then the chance for business. He says money is still from 2 to 5 per cent per month. & City of St Anthony now paying 3 u u u u u. He said one man who got his board for a year past for the interest of $300.00 Had I better raise what money I can at DuQuoin, and go up there & look?
Isaac
Chicago, June 22 1855

Isaac. Chicago June 22, 1855
Milo-June 1855
(Pencilling - thoughts about a home. Where shall it be?)

Isaac. DuQuoin, July 1. 1855
Brownville, July 18. 1855
(Retrospect thoughts about DuQuoin)
DuQuoin Station I.C. R.R.
Perry Co. Illinois
Sabbath, July 1st 1855
My Dear Wife
How the time passes! Here I am writing July! This reminds me of some other July, which you too remember, and of our anniversary, so soon to arrive. I did very much want to be with you on that day, and even when I left Bangor had some little hope of it. Three years of wedded life! How happy you have made them for me! I fear I have not done as well as I ought in making them every way pleasant to you. You know I do want to, Ettie; but somehow the effort I make to effect it seems very little. How good our God has been to us in the three years. True we have been separated a good deal; but yet how happy we have been together. You have been tried by suffering & wearisome sickness; and Oh! there was one day, when Dr Wall spoke discouragingly, and I really feared; Oh I thought my heart would break that day; but you never knew it. But the Lord has delivered us, and surrounded us with his great mercy. He has given us that which is now the light of our eyes, and the pride of our hearts, our darling boy. Here as I sit at this desk of Mitchells; (my old desk, at which I have sat so many days & nights) how

how often I catch myself looking up to reach to that remembered nook where I kept that beautiful daguerrotype of Mayo, and the other of Ettie's self! How often they consoled me during that long last Summer. In those three years too God has blessed us in basket and store. It was really but little that we had when we were wed. --little but true hearts and skilful hands. And now I suppose we have what then we might perhaps have considered a competence. The prospects of this DuQuoin property are I think better & better. It is true, on account of the hard times, there has been little sold, and less realized of late. But I would not now dispose of my interest in it for $5000.00. This coal business must rapidly bring it forward. On one 40 acres of it we have sold about 2/3 of the lots, for some $3000.00 of which I have received some and shall about $1000.00 more this fall. The other third will probably bring us $1000.00 each additional. Then there is 360 acres of land yet untouched. For the least valuable parts of this we are now getting $20.00 per acre. Some of it does not lack offers indeed at $50.00 per acre. So it cannot well net me less than $5000.00 or more and may perhaps $10.000.00. Besides all this you know I have out here 480 acres of land in other places, for some of which I could now get $10. per acre, and which may probably in a few years all bring that price. Then you know I have most $4000.00 at Bangor. In fact Ettie we could have enough so we could settle tolerably most anywhere; The only difficulty is our property is invested where we cannot well get at it just now.

Evening. I have been down to the old Town to Meeting again today; Rode Mr Keyes' Jennie, and had a fine ride. Mr Albert Smith preached for the last time for the present. He is just leaving now & probably will accept the H.M. Soc. Agency, in which case he will not return in Sept. It was also Communion this afternoon.
When I went down before I did not go near the old place. Today noon I did, and hardly knew whether to laugh or cry. Inside it is simply a deserted house, and does not look much more than when I returned there last Summer, and found no Ettie there. But around the house! The Gardens , why you could not crowd your way through it. Weeds & every thing else, as thick as a mat six feet high all over it. A perfect tangle, flowers, vegetables & weeds just as thick as they can stand, in that rich soil striving for preeminence. You remember a little row of peach sprouts across the bottom of the garden two or three feet high maybe. They were never transplanted and there they stand close together, but Trees, 15 or 20 ft. high & covered with peaches! That great pear tree south of the house is as tall & vigorous as ever, but is hardly to be seen; it is only one mighty pyramid of grape vine, & well covered with largest of clusters. The way to the 'Cape of Good Rope?' is entirely blocked up with weeds & boughs. All round the house it is the same. Every window is shut up by thickest curtain of leaves. The Rose bushes are most mighty & multitudinous, but a perfect snarl with every thing else. The Trumpet Honeysuckles cover the roofs in their gorgeous pride. In the yard north & west of the house, is in parts a forest rather than a lawn It is astonishing to see the rapidity of vegetation in this country. Nothing has been pruned or dressed. You remember the Ailanthus Trees. They grow some. Their sprouts now cover half the yard, 10 or 12 ft. high.

I pushed my way through the copse, past the catalpas, the Crab the Fringe Tree, the Cherries etc. on the old office path we trod so often. You would not know it. And when through to the fence, the office corner is a nice patch of corn! The other corner, where Smith's store was is a smart patch of seeds, Mrs Shinney's house even is not to be seen for shrubbery; and the is the case with most of the houses. And the roads are grown up with weeds.
There I guess I have given you a pretty good idea of Old Duquoin as it now is. As for the country around, it is smartly fenced up, and has fine crops on it, lots of Maclura hedge growing. I saw today corn 10 or 12 ft. high; other just coming up. 
I did very much hope to get a letter from you yesterday but it did not come. I shall be ready to leave tomorrow noon, but shall wait till night in hope to get a letter. All at DuQuoin inquire diligently for you. All want to see you there again.
You will write to St Paul, I hope before you get this, and afterward to Elyria. 
Good night Ettie
Isaac S.

Isaac. Bangor Aug 21.1855
Milo Aug 23 1855
Bangor, Aug. 21 1855
My Dearest,
I thought all day yesterday how you would be expecting a letter when the mail came last night. But you know a letter to go up Monday must be mailed on Saturday, and we did not get down till 8 or half past. And then thought we  might get away perhaps today or tomorrow. But the Lawyers I must see are out of Town one of them is expected back tomorrow or next day, and I will hope to go back to Milo on Friday at farthest. But it is uncertain.
I have kept thinking of you ever since we left Milo: It troubles me that you should have to get up in the night all the time to care of Mayo: and to lift him too. I hope you will not do it much. No matter the Bed--even 'Mine Me Crib bed' --had better suffer than you yourself. 
We had quite a comfortable ride down here. Though the road is very bad--so much rain, and so much heavy teaming. Mother was somewhat tired At Lucy's we found Mr & Mrs Packard and, Mr & Mrs Jos. & Mary Sykes and the house pretty full. However Mother staid till Sunday, & then went down to Eliahs

Gertie has been very sick. I guess that a week ago, they pretty much gave her up, the Dr & All. They have had Dr Payne all the time, but they left off giving her Medecine and she got better fast. Sunday morning they thought her worse again, but she got better and yesterday seemed quite smart, but I suspect she ate too much perhaps and today is worse--the discharges frequent have returned, and they are again quite alarmed. I am extremely sorry for them. Their state of mind is bad one. The child is quite sick, and they do not know what to do for her. They have lost lost confidence in all the physicians, and do not know any thing what to do.
The fact is there is scarcely any thing more desirable--more entirely essential to any mental comfort--than Faith--First I suppose is faith in religion--in ones religious teaching, and system; and next certainly to that much be ranked faith in one's physicians. In fact as we most of us, I am afraid, have a bad habit of thinking more of our bodies & what concerns them, than of our souls, & their interests. I am by no means sure that we do not at present suffer more from lack of faith in our doctors than from lack of religious faith.

Samuel went yesterday to Boston; will probably be back on Wednesday or Thursday. There is not much to be done in the Garden nowadays, and I am rather short of business if I have to stay here most of the week. The Garden is fine--produces Peas, Beans, Beets, Corn, Potatoes etc. besides flowers innumerable. 
Lucy says tell Nettie She has so much 'on her mind' nowadays that she can not think of any thing to write. She has been full of company, but her health seems to be very good Young Jos. Sykes proposes to send her a couple of brace of doves, choice varieties Fantails & Tumblers. 
Percie is in prime health. Though he eats little but crackers & such like. Lucy has made Ten Gallons of Currant Wine! Is that according to Maine Law? Mr Packard is somewhat sick, and unable to preach last Sabbath. Jos. & Mary Sykes left for Boston on Monday. 
Please kiss Mayo several times, but do not try to lift him much or at all. 
Sincerely
I.S. Metcalf

Isaac  Warwick Jan 5 1856
Dunbarton - Warwick, Mass. Jan. 5th 1856
"Aunt Conant's"

Dearest   Well we are not yet at Elyria! We got to Brattleboro nicely Thursday afternoon, and stopped over night, and were you know going right on Friday, to get to Elyria today. But, about as I anticipated, Mother could not get by so near without coming out to see Aunt Betsy. So under pretense she feared we might be delayed, and not get to Elyria before Sat. Night, she concluded to 'just' come out here. So we came down to Northfield Friday got a horse & nice covered sleigh & got over here last night, stopping by the way to send word to Aunt Esther to come over here this morning. And this afternoon we are going back to Northfield, and spend the Sabbath there, and go on Monday Morning, having the week before us.  I suppose it was best to merely ride out here, it does Mother so Much good as well as the rest of them.  So here they are, the three old Ladies
 Betsy Conant  born  May 11 1781
 Anna Metcalf     "     March 2 1787
 Esther Stevens  "     Feb 10   1759

Three pretty smart old women I think   I wish you could see them. You must sometime.

Sabbath P.M.  Well I did not mail this letter last night, because it would start no earlier than 9 A.M. Monday.  I did intend to mail another to you before we went out to Warwick.  We came back very safely & pleasantly yesterday afternoon, got here before night. Mother very well - not tired or cold at all.  Today, very stormy, Mother has not been out at all. I went to the Unitarian Church. There was no meeting in the other. I was not very greatly edified by the polished Essay upon "the great multitudes that no man can number". I did not remain to the Communion, or to see the dozen or more admitted to the Church. Tomorrow morning we shall start again on our journey though we may stop at Greenfield, and not get to Elyria till Tuesday night or Wednesday morning.  I am getting in a hurry, for I am anxious

to hear from you & the little ones, and suppose I can not until we reach there. My Old Chief & chum, Mr A.R. Field is now at Greenfield, upon the Tunnel Route, and hearing I had been at Brattleboro & gone out to Warwick, wrote to intercept me here. very urgent indeed to have me stop then a little while at any rate. I may do so. I have not seen him since I first went West. 
I tell Mother I shall tell Anne, & write to Lucy that she (Mother) has been out riding (by horse) the tree coldest days this Winter! What will they say to that? Yesterday the Thermometer was not above Zero F. at any time all day here. 13  below in the morning. However Mother was very well protected. She had on Aunt Hannah's great Wadded Cloak & Capes, with Shawles all over her head and shoulders, & then closely wrapped up in a covered sleigh, so she could not be cold. I did want to go over to Royalston & perhaps should yesterday morning, if I had had a good horse.
You must go around here sometime Nettie.

I want you should write very often & as particularly as you have time, but write, if it is only a few words, just to let me know you are well with the little ones. No matter if you send two letters the same day to different places, one to Chicago & one to DuQuoin. I fear this letter will not get around to Concord in Season for Tuesday's mail.
We thought a little of calling at Mr Hatch's in Warwick, but had hardly time. However Aunt Esther told us all about Mrs Hatch's family. I will tell them about us. Mr Hatch you know is dismissed, & a little quarrelsome about it I guess. It troubled the good Aunt Esther to tell about it. All the rest of our relatives about here are Unitarians.

Isaac Elyria Jan 12, 1856
Dunbarton.Jan 17-1856
Elyria Ohio, Sat. Jan 12. 1856
My Dearest One
Well, we have at last arrived here safe and sound. After waiting three days at Buffalo, came here very comfortably in one day, and without much fatigue to Mother. Arriving here I was rejoiced with your letter, that of Jan. 3d written & sent only the day after we started, and which arrived here I believe they say on Monday last. I suppose it made the journey before the great storms, and nothing has gotten through the mighty blockade since till now. I trust you have written several times, and that a number of letters are one the way: and I hope will reach here tonight. 
It seemed good I assure you to get a letter from you written only even one day after I left there, to know that the little one's mouth were better, and how you all got along the first night; but I am still anxious enough to hear later new from you all. I know you have written, and I think letters will come to hand tonight. 
We did have rather a long and somewhat tiresome delay at Buffalo, from Tuesday till Friday. However we were pretty comfortably situated at the Hotel. For three whole days there was no Train got through the snow drifts on the Lake Shore Road between Buffalo & Erie or Cleaveland. And at Cleaveland there was but very little snow. At Buffalo, there was not really a great deal of snow, but a constant storm and very much wind from Monday till Friday.

At Chicago the Thermometer was one day 24 below Zero, and another 19 below. Here & at Cleaveland, it was 17 below. I suppose you have seen some accounts of the storm in New York City & elsewhere a week ago tonight, Sat. Jan. 5th. But it was no so severe farther north. Did I mention to you something of the night we spent at Albany? last Monday night Jan. 7th. We stopped at the Delevan House, you remember it, the great Temperance House. It was very stormy, a great wind and snow. I got rooms for Mother & I connecting, and ordered a fire at once in Mother's. It did not seem to kindle--they were having much difficulty to start fires in many of the flues--In my room they got a good fire started, and so I changed & put mother in the smaller room I had designed for myself. Afterwards the fire in my room got to burning, and it seems with the flue stopped up, or it got stopped up with snow. Mother did not sleep well, and in the night, perhaps one o clock, Mother thinking her room too warm, opening the door through into mine. There was a great fire, the room very hot, and--I lay there stretched out on the floor--suffocated with the coal gas! What do you think of that? I was not entirely insensible, that is, I could move some, could get up, or try to, and fall down again. I could try to talk, though at first could not say any thing; and did not really know any thing until I waked the next morning. The wonder is that Mother was not frightened to

to death; I expect she was almost. She worked over me some, and called for help. The Landlord, one who has charge of the house by night you know, came at once, (on learning the matter from the Porter who answered the bell), and he attended to the case himself closely I warrant you. He would not call a Physician, for the sake of the house you know. (Such a thing known might injure the reputation & business of the house! . He worked over me by the hour, rubbing me etc walking me about, leading me around the halls etc etc And of it all I knew nothing! In the morning I waked up with a most horrible head ache, and finding myself in another room from where I went to sleep, with only a dim impression, like the faintest of dreams, of walking about the house with some one, and then getting into a bed very cold & sleepy. I suppose I had really rather a narrow escape. If Mother had not looked into my room in the night--it might have been too late in the morning. 
It is curious; I have thought of it many times since, I had a strange presentiment of evil after leaving Dunbarton, a feeling very different from any I ever experienced It was every night till that Monday night a strange sort of dread, an undefinable fear of something I knew not what; a feeling of impending evil. To be sure, it was about you, or the children I kept thinking the children must be sick. Sometimes I almost felt it enough to turn about & go back to Dunbarton, if Mother had not been with me. But the next morning after

after the suffocation at Albany, it seemed all clear to me. Now is there not that something curious about that
Ore.
To be sure I felt better when I got here & got your letter and better yet now I have just read yours of Jan. 7 About that Pocket Book, is it not a little strange? I certainly thought it was about $75. instead of $55, in it. You can tell which it out to be. I had about $150.00 when we left Bangor; add up in the Expense Book & deduct, and you have about the amount it should be. 
Father's fingers, I don't think he takes pains enough to protect them. I wish he had my Fur Mittens. He ought to wear two or three pairs when he goes out. 
Do you play out in the barn with Mayo? It is much better for both of you than the sewing (which I fear you do). I mean to start for Chicago Monday, or Tuesday at any rate; for I fear I shall get no more letters till I get there. 
Sabbath--an enormous snow storm here. Heretofore the weather has been very cold here, but with little snow just here. I fear I shall not be able to get to Chicago immediately, & I fear I will not hear from you again till I do.
You must frequently to Mother I suppose you wrote last week to Chicago. This week you will write to DuQuoin. You had better write mainly to Chicago rather, and here perhaps.
Mother will write to you soon
Love & Kisses to Mine own
Isaac

Isaac Decatur  Jan 29. 1856
Dunbarton  Feb 5. 1856

 Decatur  Jan 29. 1856

My Dearest   It is my Birthday today. Only to think of it, I am today 34, thirty four years old. It makes me feel almost an old man to think of it. How short the last twelve months seems; and in twelve more, short & fleeting as were those, I shall have reached, if I live till then, one half of Man's appointed three score years and ten. And this is far longer than I can expect my life to be prolonged. And yet I seem to myself to have but just begun to live, in fact not seen yet to be fairly started and ready to live a life which is really living. Till some three years and a half ago, "since we were Wed, Ettie", I hardly realized what it was to live.  Well, shall the latter days be better than the former? Help me, Ettie, Mine own, that, at least, I may do my part better than I have done.

I believe I wrote to you Sunday. Monday I spent the forenoon down in the coal mine: quite well worth visiting too. Their galleries extend more than a quarter of a mile already; chambers cut in the coal in all directions. Quite a populous place too. A hundred or two of Miners are at work there. They do not live down there yet.  But they have a half dozen mules down there who do, and who are never likely to see day light again. It seemed curious to go down in there from the cold out doors, the snow, and men wrapped up in furs, and see the Miners at work half naked; many of them nothing on but a pair of drawers or thin pants & shoes. Down in the Mine, you know, is an equable summer temperature all the time.  Afternoon I took Mr. Keyes' mare Jenny, and rode down to Old DuQuoin, called at Dr Wall's, Hiram Hinckley's & c.  And went round the old place; it looks bad enough, I assure you. It is just as it was when I was there last

Summer, only more so. doors all open, hogs in or out as they please and furniture & everything all there Books & all, as left down stairs. It is lucky the  hogs do not go up stairs for up there bedding &c. is all over the floors!  It is really strange.   Today, I left DuCoign at 10.35 A.M.   7 P.M. reached here.  You remember Mr Marshall wished me to call on his wife's folks here. I shall stop here tonight and till 10 oclock tomorrow morning. I could call there just as well as not, and would, but ___ I cannot for the life of me remember the name. I noted it in my Memorandum  book, but I left that at Dunbarton  I expect I will find a letter from you at Chicago. I want it bad.   Your own  Isaac S.

Isaac

Matteson House Chicago
Sabbath, Feb 3 1854

Dunbarton  Feb 9  Noontime  1856
Dearest   I got nicely taken in this forenoon. I thought I was getting into the New 2nd Congregational Church a very neat pretty house just finished, got a comfortable seat, and begun to feel quite at home, when I happened to see must before me old John Pierpoint  So I looked round for a Hymn Book & found it the Unitarian Hymn & Service Book, a Boston Unitarian Liturgy & Hymn Book. About that time I saw the Minister earnestly inviting old Pierpoint to preach but he would not. It was rather too late to back out, so I sat and heard quite an Elegant Essay upon the duty of joining the Church by Rush R Shippen the only Unitarian Minister - of the only Unitarian Church at any rate, of Chicago. He seemed to be a pretty smart young man & I think the first & only Minister of this only church. They are evidently wealthy though, and this their new church, though very plain both outside and in, is in excellent taste, as well as large & somewhat expensive.

I have barely seen a building whose interior finish & decoration suited me any better, very plain, but massive & elegant, and in perfect keeping throughout.  Did you know the Unitarians ever used a Liturgy. This Church had one, regular forms of prayers, responses by the congregation &c. &c.  A little like the Episcopal, though congregationally modified. This was gotten up by rev Mr Waterston of one of the Boston Unitarian Churches.  Well, I have just got a good dinner, plenty of White Fish & Prairie Chicken &c. &c.  Now I will try to make out better in Church going this P.M.

 P.M.  Well, I did make out rather better I got into the First Presbyterian Church of Chicago. The Pastor, Rev Mr Harvey Curtis, after the introductory exercises, said that, at the beginning of the year, in a historical sermon, upon the history of Churches & religion in Chicago, he had told them that it was less than 23 years since a young man landed at the then far out of the way Fort Chicago, whose efforts soon succeeded in founding the

First Church of Chicago with 7 members  This is now that First Church of Chicago. And, continued Mr Curtis I now have the pleasure of introducing to you that young Missionary who 22 years ago formed this First Church of Chicago, Rev Mr Porter of Green Bay. Then the said Mr Porter, quite a young looking man by the way, I think most any one would call him under 40 rather than over, proceeded to preach a very good sermon upon Acts 1   The promise of the Holy Spirit, and especially to the children of the Church.  This 1st Pres. Church, a very fine large house with a large Society, (though the 2d Pres. Mr Patterson's is the Aristocratic Church), stands on the very spot where Mr Porter organized his first Church at Fort Chicago. It seemed a little strange to think that so young looking a man could have formed the first feeble church in what is now this great city of almost a hundred thousand souls. And how many years too since then Chicago, as a place of business merely struggled

merely struggled for existence. It shot forward rapidly in 37 ~ 39, when Illinois tried so hard to be something ~ but after that almost went backward. Its grand strides to greatness have been within the last four or five years.  Mr Porter is a very good preacher, but he is  not accustomed to preaching in big houses, and he tried too hard to fill the house, and hurt his voice. 

Eve. I did intend afternoon or evening to have gone to the Plymouth Church, but they have pulled down their old Church, where I have been, and built another ever so far up town, and it has been cold and windy today that I did not like to hunt it up. So this evening I strayed into a Methodist Church evidently a big & prosperous one. The Preacher a big stout man who would evidently be lazy if he was not a Methodist. As it is, he certainly thundered away well. I do like to hear a real large hearted big headed Methodist preacher. His subject was the Pool of Bethesda, and his sermon a thoroughly Methodist one. The Blind were Sinners, the withered were Backsliders, the halt, lame, imperfect Christians, not sanctified.  "But, blessed be God, the Angel comes down now every day, and the Pool is troubled all the time."  Well he is quite a preacher; I wish I knew his name.  Whether I shall get to Milwaukee tomorrow or not I cannot yet tell. big train did to through today but I would not go   Good night & all blessings   Isaac

Isaac. Chicago  Feb 2. 1856                                                 Office of the Illinois Central R.R. Company

Dunbarton  Feb 9, 1856                                                            No. 48 Michigan Ave,

                                                                                             Chicago,  Feb 2 1856

My Dearest

 Here I am again writing to you;  Mainly perhaps for the lack of anything else to do; and when I sit down to pen, ink and paper I most naturally begin to address myself to you.  I wrote to you last night, but there is not knowing when letters will reach their destinations, or even start now a days. So one may as well keep writing, even if there is nothing new interesting or important to write. I wrote last night how I was detained here and Milwaukie, and was likely to be until Monday at least. Shall I confess to you what I did after having written to you. I had overlooked the papers for lectures or subjects of entertainment  I found that Mr Wight the Editor of the Prairie Farmer was to lecture at Gregory's Com. & Ag. College, upon Agricultural tools &c. So I hunted up the place, and listened quite interestedly to his comparison of the Agricultural tools

tools of different ages and countries, and special glorification of Illinois & Chicago as bearing the palm high above all others. Its steel plough very far above all others; and the Reapers, Mowers, & Threshers taking undenied preference above those of the World.  This lasted from 7 oclock to 8. But the long evening after that!  What do you think I did. "Satan finds some business still for idle hands to do". What a complication of circumstances of temptation; Nobody who knew me, no possibility of being recognized; safe from detection, or fear of injury to others by my bad example !   What did I do?   I went to the Theatre ! ! !  Yankee Locke, the great comedian was most prominently advertised to appear in sundry farces, comedies & c. So I went in, and sat very gravely through the whole performance - could not help laughing though sometimes at the jokes and fun of the Said Yankee Locke's caricatures of the Yankee Character.  It was something like my friend Hanscom of College Memory  who: shut himself very carefully in his room and deliberately got drunk, merely as a grave philosophical, and physiological experiment.

And like Hanscom's, I guess the experiment of Theatre going will suffice.  Today, I have been reading one of Walter Scott's Novels, 'Anne of Gierstien', all the forenoon, and this afternoon have wandered out to the R.R. Office; partly to have some one to talk to; partly in slight hope of finding another letter from you; and partly to find a good chance to write. So here I sit in Mr Mason's own private room: himself writing before me, and his private Secretary, Mr Malmberg, a learned Norwegian, by my side.  Mr Mason is not only a very busy man, but a man of a very great deal of business; more than any man I ever knew anything about. But I take care not to interfere with his business.  This waiting here does make me long to start for home; but I shall stick it out a while.  I am not going to the Theatre tonight.   Much - All love  Isaac    P.S. Do not let your economy be alarmed at the thought of my Postage Bill, for just here paper & postage envelopes do not cost anything!

Isaac  Milwaukee Wisconsin                                             Office of Engineer and Superintendent
Feb 5. 1856                                                                         Milwaukee & Watertown Rail Road

Milwaukee, Feb 5 1856

My Dearest

 Well I do not know as I have anything to say today; except that I am agreeably disappointed in Milwaukee. It is a much finer place than I had supposed. The Harbor & much of the business is along a little river about the level of the Lake like Chicago: but back, and between the river & the Lake the ground rises finely., so that on one side of the Town the Lake Shore is pine bluff, which must be nearly 150 feet high. Fine wide streets too and many nice buildings. It must be healthy & pleasant in that part of the city at least. On the whole it is more of a city and better situated than I had supposed.  Pop 30,000+  The Eng. & Sup. of this road, newly appointed is my old Comrade E.? Q. Sewell, once of Vt. & Mass. R.R.   Ettie, I am almost discouraged about Engineering. I believe I have not spunk to crowd myself into business. There are a good many more applications than

than there are situations, or business for the applicants. And every one who has power or influence in such matters, has plenty of relatives or particular friends whom he wishes to help along.  The opportunities for a modest man like myself, who is without influential connections are my no means good.   What shall I do?   It is not discouraging to feel the ability to do something, and do it well, and find no sort of opening to begin to do, however much one wishes.  What shall I do, Ettie?   Give it up?   I am going to Madison this afternoon, 4 P.M.  Probably stay there tomorrow, and perhaps return to Chicago the next day.   My love to you all, and may Gods blessing go with it.   Sincerely  I.S. Metcalf

Isaac  Madison  Feb 6, 1856                          Madison, Wisconsin
Dunbarton Feb 19 1856                                   Wed. Eve. Feb 6. 1856

(delayed)

My Dearest

 Well, I have not bought City property in Madison yet. Really though I came nearer to it than I ever did anywhere else. I have really found something that almost suits me. The only lack appears to be that I have no business occupation here, or any proposed of it. If I had I think I might be pretty well suited here.  Now would it do to move here this spring, hire an office, and set up a shingle  Civ. Eng. & Land Surveyor.  I might possibly earn enough to starve? upon for half a dozen years to come. What do you think of it?   The property is 4 lots each 4 Rods x 8 Rods, well fenced, one or two cross fences. Most of it a beautiful & well cultivated garden, some forest and ornamental trees around it, and throughout plenty of choice young fruit trees, Apple, Pear, Peach, Plum, Cherry, just beginning to bear. Claims to have had the nicest peaches in the State last year.   Currant & gooseberry? bushes. A good well. A first rate stable 17x21, two stories in good shape, new, built for a house. Then the House! I wish you could see it!  It would make a fine Martinhouse, after we could build a nice dwwelling house.  Let me describe it - beginning at the front door. 
                                             West is the house

Front Entry 4 ft. square            Bedroom 6x8
Parlor       12x14                      Kitchen 8x12
Closet & Chimney 4x4             Closet 4x5
Stairway   4x4                          Entry 4x5
Chamber in roof                         These in a leanto addition, and a shed back of that  

That is the house itself

sketch of rooms: Cistern  Shed  Summer Store
Bedroom  Kitchen  Closet  Entry
Stair  Closet  Parlor  Entry     Well (outside)

The Situation is a beautiful one; one of the finest about the city - It is nearly 3/4 of a Mile from the State house, In what must be a very fine part of the city eventually. It is on a pine ridge, partly overlooking both lakes. The price is about the same as three thousand dollars cash $3000.00   They call it $3300.00 or $3200.00  It is $1500.00 cash, or rather $630 now, and $590. June 16 being a Mortgage; and $1700.00 in 12 Mos. without interest.  The lots unimproved are worth as they are selling around these say $600.00 apiece or near that. The fence is good & new, painted picket fence  The house is is made on purpose, thoroughly made, all bricked inside &c well painted, Window blinds throughout. Needs new papering. It belongs to an English Man, a retired Captain of Eng. Army who has got homesick, and wants to quit.  The probability is these lots will in a few years be worth $1000.00 apiece. At least so they say here.  At any rate it is a good bargain, as all property is selling here. I have been looking all day & like the country. But the question is what shall I do for a living if we settle here.  Can I not do better somewhere else.  So I have not made the bargain.  Though they say it will be worth a third more next spring!

Isaac  Bangor May 22 1856
Dunbarton  May 27 1856

 Bangor ME May 22d   Thursday evening
 Dearest Ettie    I did intend to mail a letter to you today at any rate; but here it is too late already; and I have not written; therefore cannot send.  We had a very comfortable journey. Spent the whole afternoon at Lawrence; arriving there about 12 oclock and remaining till about 6 P.M.  Anna, Mayo & I walked about all over Lawrence, shopping; that is looking at shops. &c. &c.  Mother remained in the Depot mostly, except looking about the falls & bridges a little. The R.R. ride was very pleasant, left Portland in Steamer Daniel Webster at 10 P.M.  It was a very fine night; I got two pretty good

good state rooms, and we were very comfortable. Mayo behaved like a regular old traveller both by Rail and Steamer, was as good as could be; few companions of any age or sex could be less trouble. I do not know but I could trust him to travel alone.  he certainly has a great faculty of taking care of himself  Arrived at Bangor at 10 A.M.  Found all well but Lucy, and they hope she is getting better, though she still coughs considerable and raises much. Maria looks very well. The little Irving is well, and has a tooth or two  He is very plump, & I should think very handsome, but very small, looks about half as large as ours.  I believe only 14 lbs.   Samuel & Eliab very busy, as usual, but I guess they have got over the worst of it, and

carried their bank through, besides. Their business seems very good indeed this Spring.  Lucy is very much glad of the apron &c. for Percie, she says not only as an expression of kindness & sympathy, but for absolute necessity. She has neither been able to sew or to get material & set others at work. The little cape is admired.   I am anxious to hear how the babies troubled you last night, and how they are well. Have Asenath help you much. Let all other things go, and let her take care of babies especially if they are worrisome. Do not get sick yourself or let your Mother.

Friday 23d

 I regret much my carelessness in not getting a letter mailed to you yesterday. I went down Town after dinner, & was gone all the P.M. & when I came back got to talking till too late, and now a letter mailed today cannot get to you on Saturday.  Today I am working in the garden some. It needs it sadly Lucy being sick, and Samuel so very busy. The Irishmen do not do very well without an overseer you know  I will hope to get a letter from you tomorrow, & am sorry you will not get one from me.   Your own  I.S.

Bangor Me, Aug 26th 1856

 Dearest    Lucy still lives, but is apparently sinking rapidly. I succeeded in getting here last night. Could not get across to the Boston & Maine by the Portsmouth & Concord, the Manchester & Lawrence, but getting to Lowell I had just time to jump upon the Salem & Lowell Train which crosses the Boston & Maine at Wilmington Junction. The Eastern Train does not stop there at all, by by running to the right spot at the crossing, and, taking advantage of the moment they check the speed at the crossing, an active man without baggage can jump on the Train while is motion. That Train left nearly 500 passengers at a Camp Meeting ground in Kennebunk Me. The extra load delayed so long that we had no time to stop in Portland for dinner.

So I had no stop from 5:30 at Concord till 8 P.M. at Bangor.  And after I ate some supper my tooth ached finely at the first part of the night.  But today I feel much better.   Lucy sits propped up by Pillows, unable to lie down, or to move at all. She can not speak hardly at all; if she tries it is hardly audible. She has lately, but very little pain except shortness of breath, only occasionally a coughing spell, & raising? which hurts her severely.   Oh, Nettie, She is dead -  While I was writing the above; it was just after twelve oclock; Maria, who had been up all the forenoon, had just gone; Samuel had just come down stairs; Mother was alone in the Chamber except Mrs. Harlow; Lucy wanted to spit, she did once very easily, then her throat seemed to fill; Mr Harlow stepped to the door & called; but in less than half a minute at once, & without a struggle, before any one reached

the room, she was gone. Mother had raised her head up to spit, and even when she laid it back, the spirit had passed.  Oh, how I wish you could see her! now.  Every trace of pain or care has gone now.  It is Peace, perfect Peace now. Mother says Lucy had been extremely anxious to live, till within a few weeks; indeed she had much to make her desire life; but lately she has been perfectly reconciled. She told me this morning that it had seemed hard to part with things here, but that now the prospect before her was 'perfect joy'. She said too she had wanted very much to see you & the little ones.  Only a short time before she died, Mother had asked her if she had any dread of death, she answered 'Not a bit, Not a bit'.

Funeral will probably be on Thursday.  Can not tell when I shall return. Write to me of everything Thursday.
on side:
Isaac   Aug. 26 1856    Bangor   

                                   Dunbarton

Isaac  Du Quoin  Jan 14. 1857
Elyria

   DuQuoin  Jan 14  57  Wed.

My Dearest   

 My Ettie, No letter from you. I am in a great strait to hear from you. Just think  I have away from Elyria one whole week now; Seven long days this morning, and do not even know how you got along the very day I left home. I do not know that the fire all went out and you and the Baby both took cold & are sick. I do not know Jennie went to the Doctor that morning, took medicine & has been sick ever since.  It is too bad of Uncle Sam's Mails to be so slow & irregular; 7 days  where a Passenger can cone in a day & a night. If I had heard from you in Season I should have gone North to Springfield & Dubuque last night, or even the night before.  As it is I wait. I shall have considerable to do here laying new Town lots &c. &c. but it is the ground is frozen too hard now for out of door work. So I have been

So I have been looking about some, and some at work making a new plan of the Town & lots &c.  My health & appetite are first rate, and I live very comfortably, sleeping & writing here in Mitchell's Den. Working in Keyes' new office; and eating sometimes at the little Tavern, and sometimes at Keyes House,  He has a family there this winter from Maine. A regular Penobscot Eirer? Man, who is working manager for a new coaling operation on the East side.   I suppose you doubtless mailed a letter the morning after I started; and I cannot see why it does not get here. If it does not come tonight, I shall be _____  ___ troubled --- or vexed.  If it does I think I shall go north by night Train: get back here not till next week.   How do you get along. You must be ? employ with Polly Ann, and have her do just right. I expect she needs training. I intended to give her a talking too before I left.

as for Jenny I hope & Trust she is well & hearty, and enjoys going to school, and at the same time is good & careful, and receives kindly and trustingly the advice of her dear Sister in all respects.  I want to play with Paul Wilder an hour this morning very much.  I should like too to stir up that furnace fire, and go to Market for you.  Write me about the new Pork barrel, and what you do with the fresh meat.  Does Jenny or any body pull the baby outdoors every pleasant day. There is a nice time at Noon is there not?   Well  Write - Write   
Lovingly  Isaac

Isaac. DuQuoin Jan 17, 1857
Elyria Ohio
DuQuoin Perry Co. Illinois
Tuesday Eve. Jan. 17. 1857
My Dear Wife,
Your letter of Feb.? 13th, last week Friday, came tonight. I am certainly lucky this week. Last week I believe I got but two letters, though I wrote five I think. This week I have received that number already. Yesterday yours of the 11th, and today of the 13th. Yesterdays troubled me some, with the pleasure of hearing from you, to think of your getting frightened about the fire. And today of your getting frightened again by the untimely caller.  A big & cross watch dog would be an excellent thing about a house to induce such callers to satisfy their desire for information some where else.
Perhaps though I should make a pretty good watch dog myself - Now I think of it I will try to come home and show my qualifications for the post.
Your letter yesterday was a nice one, and one from Jennie too; but my letter last night I guess was only a scrawl. I only wrote a little while waiting for my supper for I was in a hurry unusually so last night.

I am unusually rejoiced at your letter received today. It is quite a mercy to me it came so speedily less time on the road I guess than any other I have had. I was unusually pleased at it, because I had been fearing all day that your fright & exposure the night of the fire might have made you sick. and I should have felt anxious about it till I got another letter, if ie had been a week.
My letters seem to be longer getting from here to Elyria, than yours from there here. You received two last Thursday seven & nine days from here; mine this week have been only four & five days from you. The Baptists are now talking of starting here at this point some kind of a school. I hardly know whether a College or a Theological Seminary, though I suppose they mean a place to educate their young preachers. It is as yet uncertain what they will do.
You have no idea what beautiful weather it is here now. Spring has come here really and in earnest. It has been to today as warm as May. The grass really begins to look quite green; and as for the wheat fields why they are already as bright as June. The Cooing, or rather roaring, of the Prairie

Prairie chickens is heard on every side.
You remember it, and can describe it to Jenny. It is about the half way sound between the roaring of Bull, and the Cooing of doves. Jenny though is hardly familiar with the cooing of doves. Turtle doves are not common in New Hampshire. I have seem them in Massachusetts.
I heard the Prairie Hens first the 12th The Frogs commenced about the same day. The Tree Toads began to croak the 11th. The post was all out of the ground here last week before the rains of Saturday Night & Sunday. Now just remember how pleasant Spring is, and wish you were now in this climate. Or think of Maine & New Hampshire, where the snow is now - well, at the least, ever so deep, and the Thermometer below Zero, and be glad you are in your present climate.
The Post yesterday passed round a Church Subscription Paper, and got almost a thousand dollars subscribed at once besides two lots from Church & Parsonage from Keyes & Metcalf. If we call the lots $200.00 each, this with Mr M's individual subscription of $300.00, and Mr. Keyes of $100.00 for his wife (and I guess he will add another hundred) makes R. & M. pretty likely?. Do you not think so? Dea, Benj. Sprague would not subscribe any thing! His brother A.J. you

remember him, they used to call him John or Alvah - the Cabinet Maker, is angry enough at him. A.J. who is not worth $500. put down $50.00& Horace Smith $50. G.S. Smith $200.00 Ed Smith $100.00 Dr Wall worth more than all the rest put together put down $20.00 They will get $500.00 from the Presbyterian Church Erection Fund, and will get enough more to build $2000.00 worth.
Well, I will go to bed. 
Lovingly thine own
Isaac

Isaac Springfield Ill.
Jan 17, 1857
Elyria          
Brown's Capitol House
